revision.comment: limited source listing to those actually used
revision.text:
{{Use British English|date=February 2015}} {{Use dmy dates|date=February 2015}} {{Infobox cricket tournament | previous_year = 1730 | previous_tournament = 1730 English cricket season | next_year = 1732 | next_tournament = 1732 English cricket season }} This article reviews what is known of the 1731 [[cricket]] season in England. Details have survived of 31 top-class matches, thirty played eleven-a-side and one [[single wicket cricket|single wicket]]. Match reports in the newspapers were increasingly common and tended to contain more detail, sometimes including the names of patrons and players. London's Tim Coleman was named in the report of a minor match in which he was playing, and referred to as "the famous Tim Coleman".
The most dramatic match of the season was the one at [[Richmond Green]] on Monday, 23 August. It ended in a riot and it is believed that the [[Charles Lennox, 2nd Duke of Richmond|2nd Duke of Richmond]] conceded defeat after the match was originally declared a draw. Of greater significance, it is the earliest match for which the team totals were recorded and have been preserved, rather than simply who won the wager.
== Eleven-a-side matches == {| border="1" cellpadding="5" cellspacing="0" |- bgcolor="#efefef" ! width="15.0%" align="right" | date ! width="35.0%" align="left" | match title ! width="22.5%" align="left" | venue ! width="25.0%" align="left" | result ! width="2.50%" align="right" | source |- | align="right" | 17 April (Sa) | [[London Cricket Club|London]] v [[Surrey county cricket teams|Surrey]] | [[Lamb's Conduit Field]] | London won by 35 runs | align="right" | <ref name=IM47>Maun, page 47.</ref> |- | align="right" | ''notes'' | colspan="4" | The ''Daily Advertiser'' reported that the match was "played for 30 [[Guinea (British coin)|guineas]] a side and, after a great deal of good Play on both sides, it was won by (Kent) by three Notches only". |- | colspan="5" | |- | align="right" | 31 May (M) | [[London Cricket Club|London]] v [[Sevenoaks Cricket Club|Sevenoaks]] | [[Kennington Common]] | result unknown | align="right" | <ref name=DC8>Waghorn (DC), page 8.</ref> |- | align="right" | ''notes'' | colspan="4" | Advance notice was given of this game and the one below, both at the same venue. |- | colspan="5" | |- | align="right" | 1 June (Tu) | [[London Cricket Club|London]] v [[Chelsfield Cricket Club|Chelsfield]] | [[Kennington Common]] | London won | align="right" | <ref name=DC8/><ref name=ACS20/> |- | align="right" | ''notes'' | colspan="4" | London played Chelsfield, then in Kent, in an evening match with a stake of 30 [[guinea (British coin)|guineas]]. This is the only time a Chelsfield team appears in the sources. |- | colspan="5" | |- | align="right" | 5 June (S) | [[London Cricket Club|London]] v [[Dartford Cricket Club|Dartford]] | [[Artillery Ground]] | London won by 15 runs | align="right" | <ref name=DC8/><ref name=ACS20>ACS, ''Important Matches'', page 20.</ref> |- | align="right" | ''notes'' | colspan="4" | Played for 50 [[Guinea (British coin)|guineas]] a side in the "old" (''sic'') [[Artillery Ground]]. Play went on for several hours and bets of between £400 and £500 were laid; those amounts were a fortune at the time. |- | colspan="5" | |- | align="right" | 8 June (Tu) | [[London Cricket Club|London]] v [[Kent county cricket teams|Kent]] | [[Kennington Common]] | London won | align="right" | <ref name=DC8/> |- | align="right" | ''notes'' | colspan="4" | An evening match played for 30 guineas. |- | colspan="5" | |- | align="right" | 16 June (W) | [[Dartford Cricket Club|Dartford]] v [[London Cricket Club|London]] | [[Dartford Brent]] | drawn | align="right" | <ref name=GB5>Buckley (FL18), page 5.</ref> |- | align="right" | ''notes'' | colspan="4" | A return match was immediately arranged, to be played on Thursday, 24 June at the Artillery Ground. |- | colspan="5" | |- | align="right" | 18 June (F) | [[London Cricket Club|London]] v [[Enfield Cricket Club|Enfield]] | [[Lamb's Conduit Field]] | London won by 14 runs | align="right" | <ref name=DC8/> |- | align="right" | ''notes'' | colspan="4" | This is the only time an Enfield team is recorded in surviving sources. |- | colspan="5" | |- | align="right" | 24 June (Th) | [[London Cricket Club|London]] v [[Dartford Cricket Club|Dartford]] | [[Artillery Ground]] | result unknown | align="right" | <ref name=GB5/> |- | align="right" | ''notes'' | colspan="4" | This was arranged immediately after the game at [[Dartford Brent]] on Wednesday, 16 June (according to the ''St James Evening Post''). |- | colspan="5" | |- | align="right" | 26 June (S) | [[Sunbury Cricket Club|Sunbury]] v [[Kent county cricket teams|Kent]] | [[Sunbury-on-Thames|Sunbury Common]] | Sunbury won by "several notches" | align="right" | <ref name=DC8/><ref name=ACS20/> |- | align="right" | ''notes'' | colspan="4" | Played for 30 guineas a side. The Kent side was organised by [[Edwin Stead]] of Maidstone. Sunbury had a leading team at the time. |- | colspan="5" | |- | align="right" | 30 June (W) | [[Dartford Cricket Club|Dartford]] v [[London Cricket Club|London]] | [[Dartford Brent]] | drawn | align="right" | <ref name=DC8/><ref name=ACS20/> |- | align="right" | ''notes'' | colspan="4" | The match ran out of time but "it was thought (London) would have won had there been time to play it out". They arranged to play again on Monday, 5 July (see below). |- | colspan="5" | |- | align="right" | 5 July (M) | [[London Cricket Club|London]] v [[Dartford Cricket Club|Dartford]] | [[Artillery Ground]] | result unknown | align="right" | <ref name=GB5/><ref name=ACS20/> |- | align="right" | ''notes'' | colspan="4" | [[H. T. Waghorn]] recorded that play did not finish at [[Dartford Brent]] on Wednesday, 30 June (see above) and the match was to be replayed at the [[Artillery Ground]] on the following Monday, 5 July. There was an advert dated Saturday, 3 July for the re-match.<ref name=GB5/> Stumps were "to be pitched exactly at two o'clock". Time in those days was determined by the local church clock. |- | colspan="5" | |- | align="right" | 12 July (M) | [[London Cricket Club|London]] v [[Sevenoaks Cricket Club|Sevenoaks]] | [[Kennington Common]] | result unknown | align="right" | <ref>Waghorn (DC), pages 8 and 9.</ref><ref name=ACS20/> |- | align="right" | ''notes'' | colspan="4" | This game is the first known to have been played in an enclosed ground, though with only a rope around the field. The newspaper report says: "the ground will be roped round and all persons are desired to keep without side of the same". The stakes were "a guinea a man"; wickets to be pitched "by one o'clock". |- | colspan="5" | |- | align="right" | 12 July (M) | [[Surrey county cricket teams|Surrey]] v [[East Grinstead Cricket Club|East Grinstead]] | [[Smitham Bottom]], [[Coulsdon]] | East Grinstead won by 5 wickets | align="right" | <ref name=DC8/><ref name=ACS20/> |- | align="right" | ''notes'' | colspan="4" | This is the only time an East Grinstead team is recorded in surviving sources. |- | colspan="5" | |- | align="right" | 13 July (Tu) | [[Chelsea Cricket Club|Chelsea]] v [[Fulham Cricket Club|Fulham]] | [[Chelsea Common]] | Fulham won | align="right" | <ref name=DC9>Waghorn (DC), page 9.</ref> |- | align="right" | ''notes'' | colspan="4" | The Chelsea and Fulham teams are rarely mentioned in the sources but seem to have played for high stakes in matches reported by the press. Their playing strengths cannot now be ascertained. |- | colspan="5" | |- | align="right" | 14 July (W) | [[Hampton Cricket Club|Hampton]] v [[Brentford Cricket Club|Brentford]] | [[Moulsey Hurst]] | result unknown | align="right" | <ref name=GB5/> |- | align="right" | ''notes'' | colspan="4" | Reported in advance only: "we hear that above £500 is already laid on their heads, neither party having yet been beat". |- | colspan="5" | |- | align="right" | 19 July (M) | [[Kent county cricket teams|Kent]] v [[Middlesex county cricket teams|Middlesex]] | [[Kennington Common]] | result unknown | align="right" | <ref name=GB5/> |- | align="right" | ''notes'' | colspan="4" | Reported in advance only: "for £50 a side". The report stresses that the contestants are "the County of Kent" and "the County of Middlesex". |- | colspan="5" | |- | align="right" | 20 July (Tu) | [[Croydon Cricket Club|Croydon]] v [[London Cricket Club|London]] | [[Duppas Hill]] | Croydon won | align="right" | <ref name=GB5/> |- | align="right" | ''notes'' | colspan="4" | The original report in ''Fog's Weekly Journal'' calls the winning team "Surrey" but a report of the return match on Monday, 26 July refers to "Croydon". As the names seem to be interchangeable, it must be assumed that the Croydon club was effectively representative of Surrey as a county at this time. This match was played at [[Duppas Hill]], home venue of the Croydon club. |- | colspan="5" | |- | align="right" | 26 July (M) | [[London Cricket Club|London]] v [[Croydon Cricket Club|Croydon]] | [[Artillery Ground]] | Croydon won | align="right" | <ref name=GB5/><ref name=ACS20/> |- | align="right" | ''notes'' | colspan="4" | Buckley's source was the ''Daily Advertiser'' on Tuesday, 27 July. Another source (''Read's Weekly Journal'', quoted in ''Dawn of Cricket'') reports that London were playing Dartford, but this match was almost certainly a return of the one at [[Duppas Hill]] on Tuesday, 20 July. "Wickets to be pitched at 1 pm under forfeiture of £10 on either side". |- | colspan="5" | |- | align="right" | 9 August (M) | "A Great Cricket Match" | [[Richmond Green cricket ground|Richmond Green]] | result unknown | align="right" | <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.jl.sl.btinternet.co.uk/stampsite/cricket/ladstolords/1731.html#1731 |title=From Lads to Lord's – 1731 |publisher=Stumpsite |first=John |last=Leach |date=2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110629140522/http://www.jl.sl.btinternet.co.uk/stampsite/cricket/ladstolords/1731.html#1731 |archivedate=29 June 2011 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.jl.sl.btinternet.co.uk/stampsite/cricket/histories/matches.html |title=Classification of cricket matches from 1697 to 1825 |publisher=Stumpsite |first=John |last=Leach |date=2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110629140003/http://www.jl.sl.btinternet.co.uk/stampsite/cricket/histories/matches.html |archivedate=29 June 2011 }}</ref> |- | align="right" | ''notes'' | colspan="4" | The ''St James's Evening Post'' on 27–29 July announced "a great Cricket match" to be held "on Monday se'nnight" (i.e., Monday, 9 August, as the term means "a week on Monday") at [[Richmond Green cricket ground|Richmond Green]] for 100 guineas "by several persons of Distinction". The [[Frederick, Prince of Wales|Prince of Wales]] was expected to be present. |- | colspan="5" | |- | align="right" | 10 August (Tu) | [[Fulham Cricket Club|Fulham]] v [[Chelsea Cricket Club|Chelsea]] | [[Parsons Green]] | Fulham won | align="right" | <ref name=DC9>Waghorn (DC), page 9.</ref> |- | align="right" | ''notes'' | colspan="4" | A return fixture to the one in Chelsea on Tuesday, 13 July. |- | colspan="5" | |- | align="right" | 16 August (M) | [[2nd Duke of Richmond's XI cricket team|2nd Duke of Richmond's XI]] v [[Thomas Chambers' XI cricket team|Thomas Chambers' XI]] | [[Chichester]] | Chambers' XI won | align="right" | <ref name=GB6>Buckley (FL18), page 6.</ref><ref name=ACS20/> |- | align="right" | ''notes'' | colspan="4" | The stake in this game was 100 guineas. No details are reported other than that Chambers' XI won. It seems that Chambers and his team all came from Middlesex so the match could perhaps be titled [[Sussex county cricket teams|Sussex]] v [[Middlesex county cricket teams|Middlesex]]. According to [[John Major]], [[Thomas Chambers (English cricketer)|Thomas Chambers]] was a forebear of [[Lord Frederick Beauclerk]].<ref name=JM56>Major, page 56.</ref> |- | colspan="5" | |- | align="right" | 23 August (M) | [[Thomas Chambers' XI cricket team|Thomas Chambers' XI]] v [[2nd Duke of Richmond's XI cricket team|2nd Duke of Richmond's XI]] | [[Richmond Green cricket ground|Richmond Green]] | Duke of Richmond conceded? | align="right" | <ref name=GB6/><ref name=ACS20/> |- | align="right" | ''notes'' | colspan="4" | This return match was played for 200 guineas and it is notable as the earliest match from which team scores are known: Richmond's XI 79, Chambers' XI 119; Richmond's XI 72, Chambers' XI 23-5 (approx.). The game ended promptly at a pre-agreed time although Chambers' XI with "four or five more to have come in" and needing "about 8 to 10 notches" clearly had the upper hand. The end result caused a fracas among the crowd at Richmond Green who were incensed by the prompt finish because the Duke of Richmond had arrived late and delayed the start of the game. The riot resulted in some of the Sussex players "having the shirts torn off their backs; and it was said a law suit would commence about the play". The source (Buckley) includes a further note which suggests the Duke of Richmond may have later conceded the result to Thomas Chambers (see match on Monday, 6 September below). |- | colspan="5" | |- | align="right" | 2 September (Th) | [[Croydon Cricket Club|Croydon]] v [[London Cricket Club|London]] | [[Duppas Hill]] | Surrey won | align="right" | <ref name=GB6/> |- | align="right" | ''notes'' | colspan="4" | Played for 11 guineas. It is reported that "a dispute arose and it was agreed to play it again on Monday, 13 September". |- | colspan="5" | |- | align="right" | 4 September (S) | [[Surrey county cricket teams|Surrey]] v [[Kent county cricket teams|Kent]] | [[West Dulwich|Dulwich Common]] | drawn (rain) | align="right" | <ref name=DC10>Waghorn (DC), page 10.</ref><ref name=ACS20/> |- | align="right" | ''notes'' | colspan="4" | This game was drawn due to heavy rain. Kent led by 17 on first innings but Surrey, with 3 wickets standing, needed just 12 to win when rain ended it. The report says the participants originally intended to continue another time but it seems they settled for the draw. |- | colspan="5" | |- | align="right" | 6 September (M) | [[Surrey county cricket teams|Surrey]] v [[Thomas Chambers' XI cricket team|Thomas Chambers' XI]] | [[Sanderstead Common]] | Surrey won | align="right" | <ref name=GB6/> |- | align="right" | ''notes'' | colspan="4" | The ''Daily Post Boy'' reported on Wednesday, 8 September that "11 of Surrey beat the 11 who about a fortnight ago beat the Duke of Richmond's men". See the game on Monday, 23 August above. The report suggests that the [[Charles Lennox, 2nd Duke of Richmond|Duke of Richmond]] conceded his controversial game against Chambers. |- | colspan="5" | |- | align="right" | 15 September (W) | [[London Cricket Club|London]] v [[Croydon Cricket Club|Croydon]] | [[Artillery Ground]] | Croydon won | align="right" | <ref name=DC10/><ref name=GB5/> |- | align="right" | ''notes'' | colspan="4" | Again the confusion between Croydon and Surrey: one report says Croydon, another says Surrey. Croydon is the more likely. This was probably the replay of the game on Thursday, 2 September (see above), but postponed by two days from the originally agreed date. |- | colspan="5" | |- | align="right" | 28 September (Tu) | [[Surrey county cricket teams|Surrey]] v [[London Cricket Club|London]] | [[Kennington Common]] | result unknown | align="right" | <ref name=DC10/> |- | align="right" | ''notes'' | colspan="4" | No post-match report was found for this match despite its being promoted as "likely to be the best performance of this kind that has been seen for some time, there being great wagers depending". It was reported that "for the convenience of the gamesters, the ground is to be staked and roped out" so it seems that enclosure quickly became common practice in 1731. In addition, the advertisement refers to "the whole county of Surrey" as London's opponents. The [[Frederick, Prince of Wales|Prince of Wales]] was expected to attend. |- | colspan="5" | |- | align="right" | ? September | [[Surrey county cricket teams|Surrey]] v [[Kingston Cricket Club|Kingston]] | [[Moulsey Hurst]] | Surrey won | align="right" | <ref name=CS4>Waghorn (CS), page 4.</ref> |- | align="right" | ''notes'' | colspan="4" | The exact date is unknown. Played for 25 guineas a side and "some thousands of persons of both sexes were present on this occasion". |- | colspan="5" | |- | align="right" | 2 October (S) | [[Mitcham Cricket Club|Mitcham]] v [[Ewell Cricket Club|Ewell]] | [[Mitcham Cricket Green]] | Mitcham won "by several notches" | align="right" | <ref name=DC10/> |- | align="right" | ''notes'' | colspan="4" | Played for a small stake, the report mentions "the famous [[Tim Coleman (18th-century cricketer)|Tim Coleman]]" who usually played for [[London Cricket Club|London]] and was in the Ewell team on this occasion. It is rarely that a player is mentioned by name in these early reports and even more rarely that he is given praise. Tim Coleman was on the losing side in this game as the home team won "by several notches". |- | colspan="5" | |- | align="right" | 2 October (S) | "A Great Cricket Match" | [[Artillery Ground]] | result unknown | align="right" | <ref name=DC10/> |- | align="right" | ''notes'' | colspan="4" | The source reports: "A great cricket match will be play'd in the [[Artillery Ground]]; it will be the last plaid (''sic'') this season; 11 of a side, stumps to be pitch'd exactly at 12 o'clock". Nothing further has been found and the match might not have been played.<ref name=DC10/> |- |}
==Single wicket== ''July''. A [[single wicket cricket|single wicket match]] was played at [[Maidstone]] between two officers of the [[Royal Horse Guards]], Captain Beak and Lieutenant Coke. It was for a "considerable sum of money" and won by Captain Beak after three hours "very hard played". Waghorn stated that it was the first military match he found during his researches.<ref name=CS3>Waghorn (CS), page 3.</ref>
==Other events== ''July'' (exact date unknown). An unusual match at [[Duppas Hill]], Croydon, between a Kent team and a Surrey team who were all called Wood. The Woods won. This is interesting given the well documented confusion over different players called Wood or Woods in the 1770s.<ref name=CS3/>
==Debutants== ===Tim Coleman=== Dates unknown, Coleman took part in the Mitcham v Ewell match (see above). Normally a London player, he was well known enough to be described as famous by the newspaper but that is the only known mention of him in sources.<ref name=DC10/>
===Others=== * [[Thomas Chambers (English cricketer)|Thomas Chambers]]<ref name=GB6/><ref name=JM56/> * [[Frederick, Prince of Wales]]<ref name=DC10/> * Captain Beak and Lieutenant Coke<ref name=CS3/>
==First mentions== ===Clubs and teams=== * [[Chelsea Cricket Club|Chelsea]]<ref name=DC9/> * [[Chelsfield Cricket Club|Chelsfield]]<ref name=DC8/><ref name=ACS20/> * [[East Grinstead Cricket Club|East Grinstead]]<ref name=DC8/><ref name=ACS20/> * [[Enfield Cricket Club, London|Enfield]]<ref name=DC8/> * [[Ewell Cricket Club|Ewell]]<ref name=DC10/> * [[Sevenoaks Cricket Club|Sevenoaks]]<ref name=DC8/> * [[Sunbury Cricket Club|Sunbury]]<ref name=DC8/><ref name=ACS20/> * [[Thomas Chambers' XI cricket team|Thomas Chambers' XI]]<ref name=GB6/><ref name=ACS20/><ref name=JM56/>
===Venues=== * [[Chelsea, London#Sports|Chelsea Common]]<ref name=DC9/> * [[West Dulwich|Dulwich Common]]<ref name=DC10/><ref name=ACS20/> * [[Parsons Green]]<ref name=DC9/> * [[Sanderstead|Sanderstead Common]]<ref name=GB6/> * [[Smitham Bottom]]<ref name=DC8/><ref name=ACS20/> * [[Sunbury-on-Thames|Sunbury Common]]<ref name=DC8/><ref name=ACS20/>
==References== {{Reflist}}
==Source books== * {{cite book |last=ACS |first= |authorlink=Association of Cricket Statisticians and Historians |title=A Guide to Important Cricket Matches Played in the British Isles 1709 – 1863 |year=1981 |publisher=ACS |location=Nottingham |isbn=}} * {{cite book |last=Buckley |first=G. B. |authorlink=G. B. Buckley |title=Fresh Light on 18th Century Cricket |year=1935 |publisher=Cotterell |isbn=}} * {{cite book |last=Major |first=John |authorlink=John Major |title=More Than A Game |year=2007 |publisher=HarperCollins |isbn=}} * {{cite book |last=Maun |first=Ian |authorlink=Ian Maun |title=From Commons to Lord's, Volume One: 1700 to 1750 |year=2009 |publisher=Roger Heavens |isbn=978 1 900592 52 9}} * {{cite book |last=Waghorn |first=H. T. |authorlink=H. T. Waghorn |title=Cricket Scores, Notes, etc. (1730–1773) |year=1899 |publisher=Blackwood |isbn=}} * {{cite book |last=Waghorn |first=H. T. |authorlink=H. T. Waghorn |title=The Dawn of Cricket |year=1906 |publisher=Electric Press |isbn=}}

{{Use British English|date=March 2012}} {{Use dmy dates|date=November 2012}}
In 2006, several allegations were made of corruption in [[English football]], by sources both inside and outside the game, including a ''[[BBC Panorama]]'' investigation. In response, the [[Football Association]] commissioned a report from [[John Stevens, Baron Stevens of Kirkwhelpington|Lord Stevens]], former Commissioner of the [[Metropolitan Police]], and subsequently an investigation was carried out by the [[City of London police]], leading to many arrests.
==Allegations==
===January – Managers=== In January 2006, then [[Luton Town F.C.|Luton Town]] manager, [[Mike Newell (footballer)|Mike Newell]] and then-manager of [[Queens Park Rangers F.C.|Queens Park Rangers]], [[Ian Holloway]] alleged that bribes were rife in the sport.<ref>{{cite news | title =FA to meet Newell over bung claim |publisher=BBC News | date = 12 January 2006 | url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/l/luton_town/4605184.stm| accessdate =20 September 2006}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | title =Newell optimistic following talks |publisher=BBC News | date = 20 January 2006 | url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/l/luton_town/4631368.stm| accessdate =20 September 2006}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | title =Holloway cynical about FA action |publisher=BBC News | date = 23 January 2006 | url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/4630844.stm| accessdate =20 September 2006}}</ref> [[The Football Association]] subsequently held talks with the two managers and established an enquiry.
===September – ''BBC Panorama''=== On 19 September 2006 the [[British Broadcasting Corporation|BBC]] [[current affairs (news format)|current affairs]] television programme ''[[Panorama (TV series)|Panorama]]'' broadcast a special investigation into corruption in English football which had begun filming in August 2005.
''"Undercover: Football's Dirty Secrets"'' included footage shown of meetings between agents, managers and high ranking football club officials, filmed undercover by [[Knut auf dem Berge]], a freelance coach posing as a prospective football agent. This footage purported to show agents and managers accepting backhanders and illegally "[[tapping-up]]" players under contract to other clubs.
These allegations included:
* That [[Bolton Wanderers F.C.|Bolton Wanderers]] manager [[Sam Allardyce]], and his agent son Craig were alleged to have accepted bribes from agents for signing certain players. Two agents, Teni Yerima and Peter Harrison, were secretly filmed, each separately claiming that they had paid Allardyce through his son. Allardyce denies ever taking, or asking for, a bribe.<ref>{{cite news | title =Agents claim manager was bribed |publisher=BBC News | date = 19 September 2006 | url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk/5360700.stm | accessdate =19 September 2006}}</ref> * Then [[Portsmouth F.C.|Portsmouth]] manager [[Harry Redknapp]] is secretly filmed discussing the possibility of buying the [[Blackburn Rovers F.C.|Blackburn Rovers]] captain [[Andy Todd (footballer born 1974)|Andy Todd]] with agent Peter Harrison, which is illegal under FA rules. However, the programme merely showed Harrison approaching Redknapp and asking direct questions which Redknapp answered. * Then Portsmouth first-team coach [[Kevin Bond (English footballer)|Kevin Bond]], first team coach of [[Newcastle United F.C.|Newcastle United]] when the programme was aired, is secretly recorded admitting he would consider discussing receiving payments from a proposed new agency involving agent Peter Harrison. This was the programme's description; it did not seem explicit from the extract broadcast. Bond was suspended and then sacked by Newcastle as a result of the allegations. * [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]] director of youth football [[Frank Arnesen]] is secretly filmed making an illegal approach or "tapping up" [[Middlesbrough F.C.|Middlesbrough]]'s England youth star 15-year-old [[Nathan Porritt]]. Arnesen offers a fee of £150,000 spread over three years as an incentive to move, although he had been advised that it was 99.9% certain that Porritt would leave Middlesbrough. Both of these allegations are illegal under FA rules. Officials from [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]] and [[Newcastle United F.C.|Newcastle United]] were also implicated in attempts to sign Porritt.<ref>{{cite news | title =Time to make a ruling that tapping up be made legal |work=The Guardian |location=London | date = 21 September 2006 | url = http://football.guardian.co.uk/print/0,,329581983-103,00.html | accessdate =8 November 2006 | first=Kevin | last=McCarra}}</ref> * Agent Peter Harrison told the undercover reporter that, to secure transfer deals with Bolton, he bribed Sam Allardyce by offering to pay his son Craig. Harrison is a FIFA-listed agent, who is based in the north-east of England. * That three different Bolton transfer signings involved secret payments from agents to Craig Allardyce, some when he was contractually banned from doing any Bolton deals. Panorama alleged Bolton's transfer signings of defender [[Tal Ben Haim]], midfielder [[Hidetoshi Nakata]] and goalkeeper [[Ali Al Habsi]] involved secret payments from agents to Craig Allardyce. Allardyce's son quit the agency business in summer 2006, and has admitted in newspaper interviews that his working as an agent might have cost his father the chance of becoming England manager. * Agent Charles Collymore, is secretly filmed in the Panorama film, saying: "There's managers out there who take bungs all day long. I would say to you comfortably there's six to eight managers we could definitely approach and they'd be up for this no problem." Later, Collymore is named publicly for the first time by Luton Town manager Mike Newell as the agent who offered him an illegal payment. Collymore also represents England cricketer [[Simon Jones (cricketer)|Simon Jones]].
The programme also claimed to have set up a sting involving handing a cash payment to an unnamed Premiership manager, but the alleged manager did not turn up at the rendezvous. The programme claimed that he had been scared off by [[Mike Newell (footballer)|Mike Newell]]'s claims being revealed that same day.
===September – Telegraph Sport=== On 26 September, the [[The Daily Telegraph|Daily Telegraph]] alleged that an unlicensed agent was paid in the deal to bring [[Tal Ben Haim]] to [[Bolton Wanderers F.C.|Bolton Wanderers]]. When the Israeli international moved to England, agent Jamie Hart – the official middle man – was paid a fee by Bolton. But he has now confirmed that unlicensed agent David Abu also received a cut of the fee for the role he played in the deal. Allardyce's son, Craig, a key protagonist in the Panorama documentary, also received a payment but when quizzed on such payments Bolton Chairman Phil Gartside confirmed he had no such knowledge.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://home.skysports.com/list.aspx?hlid=418332&CPID=8&clid=30&lid=3&title=Bolton+in+fresh+transfer+probe |work=Sky Sports |title=Sky Sports – Football – Premier League – Bolton Wanderers |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090218180946/http://home.skysports.com/list.aspx?hlid=418332&CPID=8&clid=30&lid=3&title=Bolton%2Bin%2Bfresh%2Btransfer%2Bprobe |archivedate=18 February 2009 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref>
==Reaction== On 3 March 2006, The Football Association established an enquiry to be headed by [[John Stevens, Baron Stevens of Kirkwhelpington|Lord Stevens]], former Commissioner of the [[Metropolitan Police]] and former head of an enquiry into corruption in cricket.<ref>{{cite news | title =Ex-police chief leads bungs probe |publisher=BBC News | date = 3 March 2006 | url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_prem/4769606.stm| accessdate =19 September 2006}}</ref> The initial findings of Stevens' report were announced in December 2006.
On 20 September, The Football Association asked the BBC to provide all of the collected evidence and announced that it would investigate these allegations. It was to investigate allegations of illegal approaches involving Chelsea sporting director [[Frank Arnesen]], [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]], Newcastle United and Portsmouth manager [[Harry Redknapp]], along with allegations "relating to players' agents and connected activities" involving Bolton Wanderers manager [[Sam Allardyce]], son [[Craig Allardyce]], Newcastle United assistant manager [[Kevin Bond (English footballer)|Kevin Bond]], and agents [[Charles Collymore]] and [[Peter Harrison (footballer)|Peter Harrison]].<ref>{{cite news | title =FA Statement re allegations | publisher = The FA | date = 20 September 2006 | url =http://www.thefa.com/TheFA/NewsFromTheFA/Postings/2006/09/FAStatement.htm| archive-url =https://archive.is/20081011092348/http://www.thefa.com/TheFA/NewsFromTheFA/Postings/2006/09/FAStatement.htm| dead-url =yes| archive-date =11 October 2008| accessdate =20 September 2006}}</ref>
All of those accused of impropriety have denied all allegations arising from the programme, including:
* '''Sam Allardyce:''' said that he had placed the matter in the hands of his lawyers.<ref>{{cite news | title =Allardyce denies Panorama claims |publisher=BBC | date = 20 September 2006 | url =http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/5363942.stm| accessdate =20 September 2006| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20061026091819/http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/5363942.stm| archivedate= 26 October 2006 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> He also said: “As a father it is painful to watch your son talk tall and exaggerate his influence for financial gain.”<ref>{{cite news | title =Big Sam: it's painful | publisher = The Sun | date = 21 September 2006 | url =http://www.thesun.co.uk/article/0,,2002390000-2006430655,00.html| accessdate =21 September 2006 | location=London | first=Shaun | last=Custis}}</ref> On 25 September he announced that after lengthy discussions his lawyers had advised that "I have a very strong case in relation to the programme, and I am planning to sue the BBC over the false and highly damaging allegations. I have therefore instructed my lawyers to prepare my case against the BBC." Allardyce added that he would discuss the matter with Bolton chairman, [[Phil Gartside]], as well as his wife before he took any final decision.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/5378842.stm |work=BBC News | title=Allardyce planning to sue the BBC | date=25 September 2006 | accessdate=22 April 2010}}</ref> Allardyce has not yet filed any legal action against the BBC, meaning the allegations remain legally unchallenged. * '''Kevin Bond:''' said that he intended to sue the BBC for libel.<ref>{{cite news | title =Bond to sue BBC over bung claims |publisher=BBC | date = 20 September 2006 | url =http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/n/newcastle_united/5365570.stm| accessdate =20 September 2006}}</ref> Newcastle United placed him on [[gardening leave]] following the broadcast, and terminated his contract on 26 September. In response, Bond issued a statement claiming that Newcastle had sacked him without investigating properly.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/n/newcastle_united/5378844.stm |work=BBC News | title=Newcastle terminate Bond contract | date=26 September 2006 | accessdate=22 April 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.thesun.co.uk/article/0,,2002390000-2006440549,00.html | location=London | work=The Sun | first=Shaun | last=Custis | title=Magpies axe Bond | date=17 May 2007| accessdate=26 September 2006 <!--DASHBot-->}}</ref> Bond was employed again within a month, as manager of [[A.F.C. Bournemouth|Bournemouth]]. Kevin Bond filed legal papers against the BBC, but withdrew the libel action, 8 days before the trial was set to commence. The BBC's claims against Bond remain legally unchallenged.
The [[League Managers Association]] demanded hard evidence: "As the organisation which represents managers we were very disappointed with the programme. There was a complete lack of substance and evidence, and if the BBC has any hard evidence it should give it to the Football Association."<ref name="news.bbc.co.uk">{{cite news| url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/5363048.stm |work=BBC News | title=LMA wants evidence from Panorama | date=20 September 2006 | accessdate=22 April 2010}}</ref> [[HM Revenue & Customs]] has also indicated it will look into the claims.<ref name="news.bbc.co.uk"/> No libel proceedings were issued by any of those accused of wrongdoing in the broadcast.
==Stevens report== It was announced on 2 October 2006 that Lord Stevens' inquiry into [[association football|football]] corruption had been extended by two months to investigate 39 transfers involving eight clubs. On 20 December 2006, Stevens presented his preliminary report, which found that while the level of corruption within English football was not as high as had been anticipated, there were several causes for concern.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/6192665.stm |work=BBC News | title=Bung inquiry targets 17 transfers | date=20 December 2006 | accessdate=22 April 2010}}</ref> Seventeen transfer deals were still subject to further scrutiny.
On 15 June 2007, Lord Stevens' inquiry issued its final report which raised concerns over issues involving 17 player transfers, involving five clubs, three managers and numerous agents and other third parties. In summary, the report stated: “there is no evidence of any irregular payments to club officials or players, and they are identified only as a consequence of the outstanding issues the inquiry has with the agents involved”.<ref>{{cite news | title = What Stevens said about each club |work=The Daily Telegraph |location=London | date = 16 June 2007| url =https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/main.jhtml?view=DETAILS&grid=A1YourView&xml=/sport/2007/06/16/sfnste116.xml | accessdate =17 June 2007 }}</ref>
Details of one of the suspect transfer deals was withheld. The other transfers about which there are unresolved issues are:
===Bolton Wanderers=== * [[Ali Al-Habsi]] (Free transfer from [[F. C. Lyn Oslo|Lyn Oslo]] – 7 January 2006) * [[Tal Ben Haim]] (Free transfer from [[Maccabi Tel Aviv F.C.|Maccabi Tel Aviv]] – 29 July 2004) * [[Blessing Kaku]] (Free transfer from [[F.C. Ashdod]] – 24 August 2004) * [[Júlio César Santos Correa|Julio Correia]] (Free transfer from [[Real Valladolid]] – 25 July 2004)
There were also unanswered concerns regarding the involvement of [[Craig Allardyce]] in a number of transactions. “The inquiry remains concerned at the conflict of interest that it believes existed between Craig Allardyce, his father [[Sam Allardyce]] – the then manager at Bolton – and the club itself.”
===Chelsea=== * [[Didier Drogba]] (£24 million from [[Olympique de Marseille|Marseille]] – 20 July 2004) * [[Petr Čech]] (£7 million from [[Stade Rennais FC|Rennes]] – 1 June 2004) * [[Michael Essien]] (£24.4 million from [[Olympique Lyonnais|Lyon]] – 19 August 2005)
“Agent [[Pini Zahavi|Pinhas Zahavi]] has failed to co-operate fully with the inquiry. There was an initial failure to disclose his involvement in a number of transfers but, more seriously, he has failed to provide the inquiry with complete bank statements due to the confidential nature of them. There has also been a lack of responsiveness by Zahavi. There remains questions relating to his relationship with, and payments to, licensed agent [[Barry Silkman]], and with Silkman's failure to initially disclose his involvement in all the transactions in which he has received fees.”
===Middlesbrough=== * [[Fábio Rochemback]] (Free transfer from [[F.C. Barcelona|Barcelona]] – 31 August 2005) * [[Yakubu (footballer)|Yakubu]] (£7.5 million from [[Portsmouth F.C.|Portsmouth]] – 4 July 2005)
The statement relating to Zahavi and Silkman above also relates to the two Middlesbrough transfers.
===Newcastle United=== * [[Albert Luque]] (£8.5 million from [[Deportivo de La Coruña|Deportivo La Coruña]] – 26 August 2005) * [[Emre Belözoğlu]] (£3.8 million from [[F.C. Internazionale Milano|Inter Milan]] – 14 July 2005) * [[Jean-Alain Boumsong]] (£8 million from [[Rangers F.C.|Rangers]] – 1 January 2005) * [[Amdy Faye]] (£2 million from [[Portsmouth F.C.|Portsmouth]] – 25 January 2005)
“There remains inconsistencies in evidence provided by [[Graeme Souness]] – a former manager of the club – and [[Kenneth Shepherd]]” (son of the former Newcastle chairman [[Freddy Shepherd]])“— apparently acting in an undefined role but not as a club official – as to their respective roles in transfer negotiations.” Souness issued a statement denying any wrongdoing: "I cannot understand why my name features in this report. I volunteered full information to Quest as a witness and I have heard nothing further from them."<ref>{{cite news |title=Stevens puts spotlight on the agents |work=The Daily Telegraph |location=London |date=16 June 2007 |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/main.jhtml;jsessionid=4BZTTXB2IWKDBQFIQMFSFF4AVCBQ0IV0?xml=/sport/2007/06/16/sfnbon116.xml |accessdate=17 June 2007 |first=David |last=Bond |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070619165819/http://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/main.jhtml?xml=%2Fsport%2F2007%2F06%2F16%2Fsfnbon116.xml |archivedate=19 June 2007 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref> The Stevens enquiry then issued a clarification: "We wish to make it clear that inconsistencies did not exist within the evidence given by Graeme Souness to Quest concerning his role in transfers covered by the Inquiry during his time as manager of Newcastle United FC and neither the Premier League nor do Quest have any concerns in this regard".<ref>{{cite news|url=http://edinburghnews.scotsman.com/sport.cfm?id=980622007 |title=Souness evidence to bung probe not in question |deadurl=yes |accessdate=26 April 2013 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071031193801/http://edinburghnews.scotsman.com/sport.cfm?id=980622007 |archivedate=31 October 2007 |df=dmy }}</ref>
“The inquiry has been unable to obtain the co-operation of the agent [[Ahmet Bulut]]” in connection with the Emre transfer.
“The inquiry is still awaiting clarification from agent [[Willie McKay]]” in connection with the Boumsong and Faye transfers. However, Quest later issued the following statement: "Further to the key findings from the final Quest report published on 15 June 2007 by the Premier League, Quest would like to emphasise that, in that report, it was clear that no evidence of irregular payments was found in the transfers in the inquiry period which involved the agent Willie McKay. Quest would also like to thank Mr McKay for his cooperation with the inquiry."<ref>{{cite news |url=http://football.guardian.co.uk/News_Story/0,,2207222,00.html |work=The Guardian |location=London |title=Quest finds no irregular payments in McKay deals |first=Matt |last=Scott |date=8 November 2007 |accessdate=22 April 2010}}</ref>
In relation to the Luque transfer: “The inquiry still has unanswered questions relating to possible payments made by agent Francis Martin, who Newcastle officials believed was working for the selling club.”
===Portsmouth=== * [[Collins Mbesuma]] (Free transfer from [[Kaizer Chiefs FC|Kaizer Chiefs]] – 1 August 2005) * [[Benjani Mwaruwari]] (£4.1 million from [[AJ Auxerre|Auxerre]] – 6 January 2006) * [[Aliou Cissé]] (£300,000 from [[Birmingham City F.C.|Birmingham City]] – 6 August 2004)
“Agent [[Willie McKay]] acted for the selling club, Auxerre, in the transfer of Benjani and for Portsmouth in the transfer of Cisse and, for the same reason as above” (still awaiting clarification) “the inquiry is not prepared to clear these transfers at this stage.” However, as mentioned above, the enquiry issued a further statement saying that no evidence of irregular payments had been found in the transfers in the inquiry period which involved McKay and thanking McKay for his co-operation.
“In relation to Benjani’s transfer, the inquiry also has identified concerns regarding the role of (agent) [[Teni Yerima]] and (third party) [[Ralph N’Komo]].”
With regard to manager [[Harry Redknapp]], his ownership of a racehorse named "Double Fantasy" thought to have been given to him by the agent Willie McKay, has aroused some suspicion. Redknapp told the inquiry that it was possible that he did own the horse but insisted that he had not made any money out of it because the horse was a failure and never won a race.
==November 2007 arrests== On 28 November 2007 it was reported by [[BBC News]] that the then Portsmouth manager, [[Harry Redknapp]], Managing Director, [[Peter Storrie]], former Portsmouth chairman, [[Milan Mandaric]], former Portsmouth footballer [[Amdy Faye]] and agent [[Willie McKay]] had been arrested by [[City of London Police]] in relation to the ongoing inquiries into allegations of corruption in football.<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk/7116823.stm Redknapp held in football inquiry] BBC News – 28 November 2007</ref><ref>[http://football.guardian.co.uk/News_Story/0,,2218469,00.html Redknapp arrested in corruption investigation] Guardian Unlimited – 28 November 2007</ref>
==2008 investigations== {{anchor|March 2008 investigations}} City of London Police continued an ongoing investigation in 2008, including a search of [[Birmingham City F.C.|Birmingham City]] in March.<ref name="mail-july">{{Cite news |url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/football/article-1035372/City-London-police-set-interview-Birmingham-chairman-corruption-probe.html |title=City of London police set to interview Birmingham chairman as part of corruption probe |date=15 July 2008 |accessdate=14 August 2008 |work=Daily Mail |location=UK }}</ref><ref name="conn-april">{{Cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2008/apr/16/newsstory.sport |title=Sullivan slams police over 'corruption' investigation |date=26 April 2008 |author=David Conn |work=The Guardian |location=London | accessdate=14 August 2008 <!--DASHBot-->}}</ref><ref name="obs-july">{{Cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk/2008/jul/13/ukcrime.premierleague1 |title=Football corruption dossier handed over to prosecutors |work=The Observer |location=London |date=13 July 2008 | first=Mark | last=Townsend | accessdate=22 April 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url = http://www.cityoflondon.police.uk/CityPolice/Media/News/twoarrestedfootballinvestigation.htm |title = News release: Two arrested in football corruption investigation |date = 10 April 2008 |publisher = [[City of London Police]] |accessdate = 14 August 2008 <!--DASHBot--> |archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20081225223242/http://www.cityoflondon.police.uk/CityPolice/Media/News/twoarrestedfootballinvestigation.htm |archive-date = 25 December 2008 |dead-url = yes |df = dmy-all }}</ref> Birmingham officials [[Karren Brady]] and [[David Sullivan (publisher)|David Sullivan]] were arrested, interviewed and released on bail in April; [[David Gold (businessman)|David Gold]] and [[Julia Shelton]] were interviewed in July.<ref name="mail-july" /><ref name="james-july">{{Cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2008/jul/24/birminghamcityfc.championship?gusrc=rss&feed=football |title=Gold faces further questioning in corruption investigation |date=24 July 2008 |work=The Guardian |location=London |author=Stuart James | accessdate=14 August 2008 <!--DASHBot-->}}</ref> [[Pascal Chimbonda]] was released from bail in June, effectively clearing him of wrongdoing.<ref>{{Cite news |url=http://www.sportinglife.com/football/premiership/news/story_get.cgi?STORY_NAME=soccer/08/06/08/manual_152357.html |work=[[Sporting Life (British newspaper)|Sporting Life]] |title=CHIMBONDA QUESTIONS ARREST |date=8 June 2008 | accessdate=14 August 2008 <!--DASHBot-->}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url = http://www.cityoflondon.police.uk/CityPolice/Media/News/footballinvestigationupdate.htm |title = News release: Football investigation update |date = 6 June 2008 |publisher = [[City of London Police]] |accessdate = 14 August 2008 <!--DASHBot--> |archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20081225223132/http://www.cityoflondon.police.uk/CityPolice/Media/News/footballinvestigationupdate.htm |archive-date = 25 December 2008 |dead-url = yes |df = dmy-all }}</ref> ''[[The Guardian]]'' reported in June 2009, that both Kevin Bond and Harry Redknapp had dropped their libel cases against the BBC, shortly before the trial. Meaning the BBC's claims are now legally unchallenged.
When questioned on the subject, the FA stated that their own investigation was still ongoing, and any charges will probably wait until the government's own investigation into football corruption has concluded.
On 14 May 2008, [[The Football Association]] dropped one of the two charges it had brought against each of six players' agents relating to alleged breaches of rules in transfer dealings at [[Luton Town]].<ref name=conn>[https://www.theguardian.com/football/2008/may/14/leagueonefootball.lutontown "FA drops charge against agents over Luton transfer irregularities"] by David Conn, ''[[The Guardian]]'', 14 May 2008</ref>
The F.A. has laid twelve charges against agents - two each against [[Sky Andrew]], [[Michael Barry (agent)|Mike Berry]], [[Mark Curtis (agent)|Mark Curtis]], [[Stephen Denos]], and [[Andrew Mills (agent)|Andrew Mills]].
The first charge was that payments were made to them by a third company, unrelated to the club and not by the club itself. All six had denied the charge and, eventually, after seven months of "investigation," the charge was dropped.<ref name=conn/>
The other charge against each agent was that they did not have written agreements, a.k.a. "representation contracts," to act for the club when conducting negotiations. F.A. stated it is continuing with that one. Denos, Manasseh and Berry have admitted the charge but Andrew, Curtis and Mills denied it and requested personal hearings.<ref name=conn/>
Agent Andrew Mills, who had never previously been charged with any disciplinary offence since he began as a [[FIFA]]-licensed agent in 1993, stated that he was disappointed by the "sensationalist coverage" of the case. "The headlines suggested there had been serious wrongdoing," Mills said. "It is now clear that was not the case."<ref name=conn/>
