{{Commonwealth Games infobox | Name = XXI Commonwealth Games | Logo = 2018 Commonwealth Games.svg | Host city = [[Gold Coast, Queensland]] | Country = Australia | Optional caption = Logo of 2018 Commonwealth Games | Nations participating = 71 [[Commonwealth of Nations|Commonwealth]] Teams | Athletes participating = 4,426 | Events = 275 in [[#Sports|19 sports]] | Opening ceremony = 4 April | Closing ceremony = 15 April | Officially opened by = [[Charles, Prince of Wales]] | Officially closed by = [[Edward, Earl of Wessex]] | Queen's Baton = [[Sally Pearson]] | Athlete's Oath = Karen Murphy | Stadium = [[Carrara Stadium]] | Motto = ''Share the Dream'' | previous = [[2014 Commonwealth Games|XX]] | next = [[2022 Commonwealth Games|XXII]] | Website = [http://www.gc2018.com/ GC2018.com] }}
{{2018 Commonwealth Games}}
The '''2018 Commonwealth Games''', officially known as the '''XXI Commonwealth Games''' and commonly known as '''Gold Coast 2018''', were an [[international]] [[multi-sport event]] for members of the [[Commonwealth of Nations|Commonwealth]] that were held on the [[Gold Coast, Queensland|Gold Coast]], [[Queensland]], [[Australia]], between 4 and 15 April 2018. It was the fifth time Australia had hosted the [[Commonwealth Games]] and the first time a major multi-sport event achieved [[gender equality]] by having an equal number of events for males and female athletes.<ref name=":0">{{Cite news|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2018-04-13/commonwealth-games-more-relevant-than-ever/9644954|title=This Commonwealth Games will be remembered as a year of 'firsts', on and off the field|date=2018-04-13|work=ABC News|access-date=2018-04-17|language=en-AU}}</ref>
More than 4,400 athletes including 300 para-athletes from 71 Commonwealth Games Associations took part in the event.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.paralympic.org/news/gold-coast-2018-commonwealth-games-come-end|title=Up to 300 Para athletes participated in the 2018 Commonwealth Games|last=|first=|date=16 April 2018|website=International Paralympic Committee (IPC)|access-date=}}</ref> [[The Gambia]] which withdrew its membership from the [[Commonwealth of Nations]] and [[Commonwealth Games Federation]] in 2013, was readmitted on 31 March 2018 and participated in the event .<ref name=":1" /> With 275 sets of medals, the games featured 19 [[Commonwealth Sports|Commonwealth sports]], including [[beach volleyball]], [[Paratriathlon|para triathlon]] and women's [[rugby sevens]]. These sporting events took place at 14 venues in the host city, two venues in [[Brisbane]] and one venue each in [[Cairns]] and [[Townsville]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.gc2018.com/about|title=ABOUT {{!}} Gold Coast 2018 Commonwealth Games|website=Gold Coast 2018|language=en|access-date=2018-04-17}}</ref>
These were the first Commonwealth Games to take place under the [[Commonwealth Games Federation]] (CGF) presidency of Louise Martin, [[Order of the British Empire|<small>CBE</small>]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://sportscotland.org.uk/about-us/what-we-do/profile/archived-articles/louise-martin-elected-as-cgf-president/|title=Louise Martin elected as CGF President|last=sportscotland|website=sportscotland.org.uk|language=en|access-date=2018-04-17}}</ref> The host city Gold Coast was announced at the CGF General Assembly in [[Basseterre]], [[Saint Kitts]], on 11 November 2011.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://thecgf.com/games/gold-coast-2018#bid-process|title=CGF General Assemble 2011|last=|first=|date=|website=Commonwealth Games Federation|language=en|access-date=2018-04-17}}</ref> Gold Coast became the seventh Oceanian city and the first regional city to host the Commonwealth Games. These were the eighth games to be held in [[Oceania]] and the [[Southern Hemisphere]].
The host nation [[Australia]] topped the medal table for the fourth time in the past five Commonwealth Games, winning the most golds (80) and most medals overall (198). [[England at the 2018 Commonwealth Games|England]] and [[India at the 2018 Commonwealth Games|India]] finished second and third respectively.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://results.gc2018.com/en/all-sports/medal-standings.htm|title=Medal Standings - Gold Coast 2018 Commonwealth Games|website=results.gc2018.com|language=en-AU|access-date=2018-04-17}}</ref> [[Vanuatu at the 2018 Commonwealth Games|Vanuatu]], [[Cook Islands at the 2018 Commonwealth Games|Cook Islands]], [[Solomon Islands at the 2018 Commonwealth Games|Solomon Islands]], [[British Virgin Islands at the 2018 Commonwealth Games|British Virgin Islands]] and [[Dominica at the 2018 Commonwealth Games|Dominica]] each won their first Commonwealth Games medals.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://thecgf.com/news/cgf-president-declares-commonwealth-more-relevant-ever-games-firsts-draw-close-gold-coast|title=CGF President declares Commonwealth more relevant than ever before as "Games of Firsts" draw to a close on Gold Coast|website=Commonwealth Games Federation|language=en|access-date=2018-04-17}}</ref>
==Host selection== {{Main|Bids for the 2018 Commonwealth Games}} [[File:Gold Coast skyline (Unsplash).jpg|left|thumb|Gold Coast was selected by the [[Australian Commonwealth Games Association]] as the official bid city from Australia for the 2018 Commonwealth Games]] On 22 August 2008, the [[Premier of Queensland]], [[Anna Bligh]], officially launched Gold Coast City's bid to host the Commonwealth Games in 2018. On 7 April 2009, the [[Australian Broadcasting Corporation|ABC]] reported a land exchange deal between Gold Coast City and [[Queensland|State of Queensland]] for [[Carrara Stadium]]. According to Mayor [[Ron Clarke]], the land would aid a potential bid for the 2018 Commonwealth Games. The land exchanged would be used as the site of an aquatics centre. In the same article, Mayor Clarke raised the question of the Australian Federal Government's commitment to a 2018 Commonwealth Games bid in light of the Government's support for [[Australian 2018 and 2022 FIFA World Cup bid|Australia's 2018 FIFA World Cup Finals bid]].<ref name="abc.net.au">{{cite web|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/stories/2009/04/07/2537125.htm?site=goldcoast |title=Gold Coast eyes 2018 Games bid with land swap |publisher=Australian Broadcasting Corporation |date=7 April 2009 |accessdate=26 May 2011}}</ref> On 16 April 2009, Queensland Premier Anna Bligh told reporters that a successful Commonwealth Games bid by Gold Coast City could help the tourist strip win a role in hosting the World Cup.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.smh.com.au/breaking-news-national/bligh-pushes-bids-for-games-world-cup-20090416-a85x.html | work=The Sydney Morning Herald | title=Bligh pushes bids for Games, World Cup | date=16 April 2009}}</ref>
"Some of the infrastructure that would be built for the Commonwealth Games will be useful for Gold Coast City to get a World Cup game out of the soccer World Cup if we're successful as a nation," she said. However the decision on the venues for the 2018 and 2022 FIFA World Cups were made eleven months prior to the bid decision for the 2018 Commonwealth Games, so the potential World Cup venues had already been chosen. On 3 June 2009, Gold Coast City was confirmed as Australia's exclusive bidder vying for the 2018 Commonwealth Games.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.brisbanetimes.com.au/queensland/gc-gets-sole-right-to-bid-for-2018-cwealth-games-20090603-bvbd.html |title=Gold Coast gets sole right to bid for 2018 Commonwealth Games |newspaper=Brisbane Times |date=3 June 2009 |accessdate=26 May 2011}}</ref> "Should a bid proceed, Gold Coast City will have the exclusive Australian rights to bid as host city for 2018," Bligh stated.
"Recently I met with the president and CEO of the Australian Commonwealth Games Association and we agreed to commission a full and comprehensive feasibility study into the potential for the 2018 Commonwealth Games," she said. "Under the stewardship of Queensland Events new chair, [[Geoff Dixon]], that study is now well advanced." On 15 March 2010, it was announced that the Queensland Government will provide initial funding of A$11 million for the 2018 Commonwealth Games bid. The Premier of Queensland has indicated the Government's support for the bid to the Australian Commonwealth Games Association.<ref name="goldcoast.com.au">{{cite news |first=Sue |last=Lappeman |url=http://www.goldcoast.com.au/article/2010/03/15/198301_gold-coast-news.html |title=Coast Games bid up and running |newspaper=Gold Coast Bulletin |date=15 March 2010 |accessdate=26 May 2011 |dead-url=yes |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120309111011/http://www.goldcoast.com.au/article/2010/03/15/198301_gold-coast-news.html |archive-date=9 March 2012 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> On 31 March 2010, the Australian Commonwealth Games Association officially launched the bid to host the 2018 Commonwealth Games.<ref>{{cite news|first=Sue|last=Lappeman|url=http://www.goldcoast.com.au/article/2010/03/31/203445_gold-coast-news.html|title=Coast Commonwealth Games bid backed|newspaper=Gold Coast Bulletin|date=31 March 2010|accessdate=26 May 2011|dead-url=yes|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110314202139/http://www.goldcoast.com.au/article/2010/03/31/203445_gold-coast-news.html|archive-date=14 March 2011|df=dmy-all}}</ref> In October 2011, Gold Coast City Mayor [[Ron Clarke]] stated that the games would provide a strong legacy for the city after the games have ended.<ref name="Legacy benefits to Gold Coast of 2018 Commonwealth Games will be huge, says city's Mayor">{{cite web|last=Degun|first=Tom|title=Legacy benefits to Gold Coast of 2018 Commonwealth Games will be huge, says city's Mayor|url=http://www.insidethegames.biz/commonwealth-games/2018/14656-legacy-benefits-to-gold-coast-of-2018-commonwealth-games-will-be-huge-says-citys-mayor-|publisher=Inside the Games|accessdate=17 November 2011|date=23 October 2011}}</ref>
On 31 March 2010, a surprise bid was made for the 2018 Commonwealth Games by the [[Sri Lanka]]n city of [[Hambantota]]. Hambantota was devastated by the [[2004 Indian Ocean Tsunami]], and is undergoing a major face lift. The first phase of the [[Port of Hambantota]] is nearing completion and it is funded by the government of [[China]]. The [[Mattala International Airport]], which is the second international Airport of Sri Lanka is built close to Hambantota. A new [[Hambantota International Cricket Stadium]] had also been built, which had hosted matches in the [[2011 Cricket World Cup]].
On 10 November 2011, the Hambantota bidders claimed they had already secured enough votes to win the hosting rights.<ref name="Sri Lanka boasting of Games bid win">{{cite news|last=Ardern|first=Lucy|title=Sri Lanka boasting of Games bid win|url=http://www.goldcoast.com.au/article/2011/11/11/365211_commonwealth-games.html|accessdate=17 November 2011|newspaper=Gold Coast Bulletin|date=11 November 2011|dead-url=yes|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111113171613/http://www.goldcoast.com.au/article/2011/11/11/365211_commonwealth-games.html|archive-date=13 November 2011|df=dmy-all}}</ref> However, on 11 November it was officially announced [[Gold Coast, Queensland|Gold Coast City]] had won the rights to host the games.<ref>{{cite web|title=Candidate City Manual|url=http://www.thecgf.com/games/2018-Candidate-City-Manual-Dec-2009.pdf|publisher=[[Commonwealth Games Federation]]|accessdate=17 November 2011|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100705075211/http://www.thecgf.com/games/2018-Candidate-City-Manual-Dec-2009.pdf|archivedate=5 July 2010 |date=December 2009}}</ref><ref name="Coast wins 2018 Commonwealth Games">{{cite news|last=Ardern|first=Lucy|title=Coast wins 2018 Commonwealth Games|url=http://www.goldcoast.com.au/article/2011/11/13/365241_commonwealth-games.html|accessdate=17 November 2011|newspaper=Gold Coast Bulletin|date=13 November 2011|dead-url=yes|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111114195049/http://www.goldcoast.com.au/article/2011/11/13/365241_commonwealth-games.html|archive-date=14 November 2011|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
{| class="wikitable" style="margin:auto; margin-left:.5em;" |- !colspan="4" | 2018 Commonwealth Games bidding results |- !City !Country ! style="background:silver;"|Votes |- | '''[[Gold Coast, Queensland|Gold Coast City]] || {{flagicon|Australia}} [[Australia]] || style="text-align:center;"| '''43''' |- | [[Hambantota]] || {{flagicon|Sri Lanka}} [[Sri Lanka]] || style="text-align:center;"| 27 |}
==Administration== The event was overseen by the Gold Coast 2018 Commonwealth Games Corporation (GOLDOC). The GOLDOC was formed in 2012 by the [[Government of Queensland]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://gc2018.com/about|title=ABOUT {{!}} Gold Coast 2018 Commonwealth Games|website=Gold Coast 2018|language=en|access-date=2018-06-12}}</ref> Its headquarters were located in [[Ashmore, Queensland|Ashmore]], a suburban region of Gold Coast.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://gc2018.com/about/contact-us|title=CONTACT US {{!}} Gold Coast 2018 Commonwealth Games|website=Gold Coast 2018|language=en|access-date=2018-06-12}}</ref> In February 2012, [[Mark Peters (sport administrator)|Mark Peters]] was appointed Chief Executive Officer of the GOLDOC.<ref>{{cite web|last=Willoughby,|first=Shannon|title=Mark Peters named as Games CEO|url=http://www.goldcoast.com.au/article/2012/02/18/392045_commonwealth-games.html|work=Gold Coast News, 18 February 2012|accessdate=14 January 2013}}</ref> The Queensland Government Minister tasked with overseeing the Games was [[Kate Jones]].<ref>{{cite press release |url=http://statements.qld.gov.au/Statement/2017/2/10/kate-jones-appointed-minister-for-the-commonwealth-games |title=Kate Jones appointed Minister for the Commonwealth Games |last=Palaszczuk |first=Annastacia |publisher=Queensland Government |location=Brisbane |date=10 February 2017 |access-date=8 May 2017}}</ref> [[Peter Beattie]] <small>[[Companion of the Order of Australia|AC]]</small> served as the Chairman of GOLDOC who was appointed on 17 May 2016 to replace Nigel Chamier [[Order of Australia Medal|<small>OAM</small>]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2016-05-17/peter-beattie-back-as-commonwealth-games-chairman/7420786|title=Peter Beattie appointed new Commonwealth Games 2018 chairman|date=2016-05-17|work=ABC News|access-date=2018-07-03|language=en-AU}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://gc2018.com/about/our-team|title=Our Team {{!}} Gold Coast 2018 Commonwealth Games|website=Gold Coast 2018|language=en|access-date=2018-07-03}}</ref>
==Preparation== ===Venues=== {{Main|Venues of the 2018 Commonwealth Games}} One of the key technical aspects of Gold Coast City's successful bid was the fact that the city had 80 percent of the planned venues in place before the bidding deadline. The vast majority of venues were located within 20-minutes driving time of the Athletes Village in [[Parkwood, Queensland|Parkwood]].
==== Venues in Gold Coast ==== [[File:Carrara Stadium, Gold Coast, Queensland 02.jpg|thumb|[[Carrara Stadium]] hosted the ceremonies and the [[Athletics at the 2018 Commonwealth Games|athletics]]]] [[Carrara Stadium]], located in the suburb of [[Carrara, Queensland|Carrara]], was the main venue for [[Athletics (sport)|Athletics]], the [[2018 Commonwealth Games opening ceremony|opening ceremony]] and the [[2018 Commonwealth Games closing ceremony|closing ceremony]]. The seating capacity of the stadium was temporarily increased to 40,000 for the games by the installation of a large temporary North Stand.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.gc2018.com/venue/carrara-stadium|title=Carrara Stadium {{!}} Gold Coast 2018 Commonwealth Games|website=Gold Coast 2018|language=en|access-date=2018-04-18}}</ref> [[File:Gold coast convention and exhibition centre.jpg|thumb|[[Gold Coast Convention and Exhibition Centre]] hosted [[Netball at the 2018 Commonwealth Games|netball]] and the accredited media centre]] The [[Gold Coast Convention and Exhibition Centre|Gold Coast City Convention and Exhibition Centre]], located in the suburb of [[Broadbeach, Queensland|Broadbeach]], hosted [[Basketball]], [[Netball]] (preliminaries) and [[Olympic weightlifting|Weightlifting]] events, also serving as the Main Media Centre and International Broadcast centre hosting over 3000 members of the worlds press.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.gc2018.com/venue/gold-coast-convention-and-exhibition-centre|title=Gold Coast Convention and Exhibition Centre {{!}} Gold Coast 2018 Commonwealth Games|website=Gold Coast 2018|language=en|access-date=2018-04-18}}</ref> The Broadbeach Bowls Club hosted the [[Bowls]] competition.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.gc2018.com/venue/broadbeach-bowls-club|title=Broadbeach Bowls Club {{!}} Gold Coast 2018 Commonwealth Games|website=Gold Coast 2018|language=en|access-date=2018-04-18}}</ref>
The [[Hinze Dam]], located in the suburb of [[Advancetown, Queensland|Advancetown]], was the location for the Mountain Bike competition. A new course was constructed to meet international competition requirements and temporary spectator seating for 2,000 spectators.
The newly built [[Coomera Sport and Leisure Centre]] hosted [[Gymnastics]] and Netball (finals).<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.gc2018.com/venue/coomera-indoor-sports-centre|title=Coomera Indoor Sports Centre {{!}} Gold Coast 2018 Commonwealth Games|website=Gold Coast 2018|language=en|access-date=2018-04-18}}</ref> The existing sound stages of the Village Roadshow Studios complex in the suburb of [[Oxenford, Queensland|Oxenford]] hosted the sports of [[Boxing]], [[Table Tennis]] and [[Squash (sport)|Squash]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.gc2018.com/venue/oxenford-studios|title=Oxenford Studios {{!}} Gold Coast 2018 Commonwealth Games|website=Gold Coast 2018|language=en|access-date=2018-04-18}}</ref> During Games mode the venue was enhanced to provide for the International Sporting Federation technical venue requirements and provide spectator seating of 3,000 (boxing) and 3,200 (table tennis). The Gold Coast Hockey Centre hosted the men's and women's [[Hockey]] events during the games.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.gc2018.com/venue/gold-coast-hockey-centre|title=Gold Coast Hockey Centre {{!}} Gold Coast 2018 Commonwealth Games|website=Gold Coast 2018|language=en|access-date=2018-04-18}}</ref> The [[Southport Broadwater Parklands]] hosted [[Triathlon at the 2018 Commonwealth Games|Triathlon]] and athletic events.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.gc2018.com/venue/southport-broadwater-parklands|title=Southport Broadwater Parklands {{!}} Gold Coast 2018 Commonwealth Games|website=Gold Coast 2018|language=en|access-date=2018-04-18}}</ref> The [[Gold Coast Aquatic Centre|Optus aquatic centre]] hosted the swimming and diving events.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.gc2018.com/venue/optus-aquatic-centre|title=Optus Aquatic Centre {{!}} Gold Coast 2018 Commonwealth Games|website=Gold Coast 2018|language=en|access-date=2018-04-18}}</ref>
[[Robina Stadium]] hosted the [[Rugby 7s]] competition and upgraded to meet World Rugby standards.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.gc2018.com/venue/robina-stadium|title=Robina Stadium {{!}} Gold Coast 2018 Commonwealth Games|website=Gold Coast 2018|language=en|access-date=2018-04-18}}</ref> The [[Elanora, Queensland|Elanora]]/[[Currumbin Valley]] area hosted the road racing elements of the cycling programme. [[Coolangatta]] Beachfront hosted the beach volleyball event.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.gc2018.com/venue/coolangatta-beachfront|title=Coolangatta Beachfront {{!}} Gold Coast 2018 Commonwealth Games|website=Gold Coast 2018|language=en|access-date=2018-04-18}}</ref>
==== Venues outside Gold Coast ==== [[Brisbane]], along with the Gold Coast, forms part of the [[South East Queensland]] [[conurbation]]. Track Cycling was held at the [[Sleeman Centre (Brisbane)|Sleeman Sports Complex]] in the suburb of [[Chandler, Queensland|Chandler]], where a new indoor cycling velodrome (Anna Meares Velodrome) was built. The Velodrome's seat capacity was 4,000 during the games mode.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.gc2018.com/venue/anna-meares-velodrome|title=Anna Meares Velodrome {{!}} Gold Coast 2018 Commonwealth Games|website=Gold Coast 2018|language=en|access-date=2018-04-18}}</ref>
The Shooting disciplines were held at the [[Belmont, Queensland|Belmont]] Shooting Centre. In [[Tropical North Queensland]], the [[Cairns Convention Centre]] and [[Townsville Entertainment Centre]] hosted the preliminary rounds of both the men's and women's basketball competitions.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.gc2018.com/venue/belmont-shooting-centre|title=Belmont Shooting Centre {{!}} Gold Coast 2018 Commonwealth Games|website=Gold Coast 2018|language=en|access-date=2018-04-18}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.gc2018.com/venue/cairns-convention-centre|title=Cairns Convention Centre {{!}} Gold Coast 2018 Commonwealth Games|website=Gold Coast 2018|language=en|access-date=2018-04-18}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.gc2018.com/venue/townsville-entertainment-and-convention-centre|title=Townsville Entertainment and Convention Centre {{!}} Gold Coast 2018 Commonwealth Games|website=Gold Coast 2018|language=en|access-date=2018-04-18}}</ref>
=== Financing === The [[Queensland State Government|Queensland state government]] spent [[Australian dollar|A$]]1.5 billion ([[United States dollar|US$]]1.2 billion) to deliver the event. Out of this, [[Australian dollar|A$]]550 million ([[United States dollar|US$]]425 million) were spent on the procurement programme. Procurement of the security and security infrastructure included contracts for four prime suppliers which delivered around 4,200 security guards. [[Australian dollar|A$]]34 million ([[United States dollar|US$]]26 million) were spent on the deployment of the armed forces to provide rapid-response squads, bomb detectors, offshore patrols and surveillance. [[Australian dollar|A$]]657 million ([[United States dollar|US$]]509 million) were spent for the construction of the venues and the Games Village.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.accaglobal.com/hk/en/member/member/accounting-business/2018/04/insights/commonwealth-games.html|title=2018 Commonwealth Games takes schedule and budget golds {{!}} ACCA Global|last=http://www.accaglobal.com|first=ACCA -|website=www.accaglobal.com|language=en|access-date=2018-05-24}}</ref> Additional [[Australian dollar|A$]]2.6 billion were spent for the transport infrastructure. Seven Games venues were upgraded and only three were newly built and they were the A$105.3 million [[Gold Coast Sports and Leisure Centre|Gold Coast Sport and Leisure Centre]], the A$40 million [[Coomera Indoor Sports Centre]] and the A$59 million [[Anna Meares Velodrome]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.sportspromedia.com/from-the-magazine/gold-coast-commonwealth-games-queensland-olympics-2032|title=Queensland after the Commonwealth Games: An Olympic destination?|access-date=2018-11-15|language=en}}</ref> More than A$6.4 million were spent on the [[Queen's Baton Relay]].<ref name=":8">{{Cite news|url=https://www.abc.net.au/news/2018-07-02/commonwealth-games-baton-relay-cost-revealed/9929258|title='Excessive costs': Commonwealth Games baton relay charged taxpayers a fortune|date=2018-07-02|work=ABC News|access-date=2018-11-15|language=en-AU}}</ref>
=== Countdown === [[File:Streets Beach (38336072865).jpg|thumb|Countdown clock in [[South Bank Parklands|Streets Beach at South Bank Parklands]]]] The countdown clock was unveiled on 4 April 2013, exactly five years from the opening ceremony of the games. The clock was shaped as a surfboard and was located at the beach end of [[Cavill Avenue]] in [[Surfers Paradise, Queensland|Surfers Paradise]]. The Countdown Clock was the first fixed element of the Commonwealth Games visual identity program.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://gc2018.com/article/countdown-games-begins|title=The countdown to the Games begins {{!}} Gold Coast 2018 Commonwealth Games|website=Gold Coast 2018|language=en|access-date=2018-06-24}}</ref>
=== Ticketing === The ticket requests began on 24 April 2017 and ended on 22 May 2017.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2017-04-05/2018-gold-coast-commonwealth-games-tickets-ballot/8417362|title=2018 Gold Coast games ticket schedule released|date=2017-04-05|work=ABC News|access-date=2018-06-21|language=en-AU}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2017-05-23/gold-coast-commonwealth-games2018--ticket-bids-close/8549398|title=Last minute rush in 1.2m bids for 2018 Gold Coast Commonwealth Games tickets|date=2017-05-23|work=ABC News|access-date=2018-06-21|language=en-AU}}</ref> The first round of tickets were allocated on 22 June 2017 via a computer-generated ballot system. About 70% of the people who applied for the tickets had received some or all of the tickets requested in the first phase.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2017-06-22/commonwealth-games-2018-tickets-allocated-not-everyone-happy/8643552|title=Miss out on Commonwealth Games tickets? Don't give up just yet|date=2017-06-22|work=ABC News|access-date=2018-06-21|language=en-AU}}</ref> In Australia, ticket prices ranged from A$10 for many events to A$495 for the most expensive seats at the opening ceremony.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://gc2018.com/tickets/pricing|title=TICKET PRICING {{!}} Gold Coast 2018 Commonwealth Games|website=Gold Coast 2018|language=en|access-date=2018-06-22}}</ref> The games expected to have 1.2 million tickets for sale. Around 1.06 million tickets were sold by 3 April 2018.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.brisbanetimes.com.au/national/queensland/140-000-tickets-unsold-one-day-out-from-commonwealth-games-20180403-p4z7m7.html|title=140,000 tickets unsold one day out from Commonwealth Games|last=Halloran|first=Emily|date=2018-04-03|website=Brisbane Times|language=en|access-date=2018-06-22}}</ref> [[Ticketek]] was the provider of ticketing services for the games.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://gc2018.com/sponsor/ticketek|title=TICKETEK {{!}} Gold Coast 2018 Commonwealth Games|website=Gold Coast 2018|language=en|access-date=2018-06-22}}</ref>
=== Volunteering === The organizing committee expected 15,000 volunteers for the games. Over 45,000 applicants applied to become a volunteer. The uniforms for the volunteers were revealed on 11 November 2017 at the [[Gold Coast Convention and Exhibition Centre]]. Former [[Gold Coast Titans]] player [[Mat Rogers]] who was present at the uniform showcase ceremony, said that the uniforms were "very Gold Coast" and it was like an "active wear".<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.goldcoastbulletin.com.au/sport/commonwealth-games/gold-coast-2018-commonwealth-games-volunteer-uniforms-unveiled/news-story/300420ceb4bcfab4a9336f86653666f2|title=Gold Coast 2018 Commonwealth Games volunteer uniforms unveiled|last=|first=|date=|website=Gold Coast Bulletin|access-date=24 June 2017}}</ref> [[Hard Yakka]] was the official supplier of the uniforms for the volunteers.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://gc2018.com/sponsor/hard-yakka|title=HARD YAKKA {{!}} Gold Coast 2018 Commonwealth Games|website=Gold Coast 2018|language=en|access-date=2018-06-24}}</ref>
===Medals=== At a charity gala held on 4 November 2017, the medals for the games were officially unveiled. Australian Indigenous artist Delvene Cockatoo-Collins designed the medals, while they were produced by the [[Royal Australian Mint]]. The design of the medals was inspired by the coastline of [[Gold Coast, Australia|Gold Coast]] along with Indigenous culture.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.brisbanetimes.com.au/national/queensland/gold-coast-2018-commonwealth-games-medals-revealed-20171104-p4ywt5.html|title=Gold Coast 2018 Commonwealth Games medals revealed|last=Crockford|first=Toby|date=4 November 2017|work=[[Brisbane Times]]|access-date=4 November 2017|location=Brisbane, Queensland, Australia}}</ref> Furthermore, Cockatoo-Collins mentioned, "the medal design represents soft sand lines which shift with every tide and wave, also symbolic of athletic achievement, The continual change of tide represents the evolution in athletes who are making their mark, Records are made and special moments of elation are celebrated". Approximately 1,500 medals were created to be distributed to the medallists and each measures approximately 63 millimetres in diameter. The medals weigh between 138 and 163 grams.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.insidethegames.biz/articles/1057493/gold-coast-2018-reveal-medal-designs-for-commonwealth-games-at-charity-gala|title=Gold Coast 2018 reveal medal designs for Commonwealth Games at charity gala|last1=Pavitt|first1=Michael|date=4 November 2017|website=Insidethegames.biz|publisher=Dunsar Media|access-date=4 November 2017}}</ref>
===Athletes village=== [[File:2018 Commonwealth Games Village, Gold Coast.jpg|thumb|2018 Commonwealth Games Village|300x300px]] The 2018 Commonwealth Games Athletes Village was located on 59 hectares at [[Southport, Queensland|Southport]], Gold Coast.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.embracing2018.com/infrastructure/projects/games-village|title=Games Village|date=18 April 2017|work=Embracing 2018|access-date=12 October 2017|language=en}}</ref> which provided accommodation and services to 6,600 athletes and officials in 1252 permanent dwellings. There are 1170 one and two bedroom apartments and 82 three bedroom townhouses which will serve as student accommodation to the nearby Griffith University. It offered services like laundry, refreshments and television and computer spaces and four residential pools. The village consisted a gym which was designed with guidance from the Australian Institute of Sport and the equipment was sponsored by [[Technogym]]. Adjoining the gym was the Athlete Recovery Area which provided services like plunge baths, including accessible baths, saunas, massage and consults from the Sports Medical personnel. The Main Dining served over 18,000 meals per day to the athletes during the games. The village also consisted of retail shops, [[Optus]] phone store, salon, bar and a games room which featured a number of arcade games, pool tables and game consoles.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.gc2018.com/article/inside-commonwealth-games-village|title=Inside the Commonwealth Games Village {{!}} Gold Coast 2018 Commonwealth Games|website=Gold Coast 2018|language=en|access-date=2018-04-18}}</ref>
===Queen's baton relay=== [[File:Gold Coast 2018 Queen's Baton.jpg|thumb|[[Gold Coast 2018]] Commonwealth Games Baton]] The Gold Coast 2018 Queen's Baton Relay was launched on [[Commonwealth Day]], 13 March 2017, on the historic forecourt at [[Buckingham Palace]], signalling the official countdown to the start of the Games. Accompanied by the [[Prince Philip, Duke of Edinburgh|Duke of Edinburgh]] and [[Prince Edward, Earl of Wessex|Prince Edward]] The Earl of Wessex, Her Majesty [[Elizabeth II|Queen Elizabeth II]] heralded the start of the relay by placing her 'message to the Commonwealth and its athletes' into the distinctive loop-design Queen's Baton which then set off on its journey around the globe. It traveled for 388 days, spending time in every nation and territory of the Commonwealth. The Gold Coast 2018 Queen's Baton Relay was the longest in Commonwealth Games history. Covering 230,000 km over 388 days, the baton made its way through the six Commonwealth regions of Africa, the Americas, the Caribbean, Europe, Asia and Oceania.
The baton landed on Australian soil in December 2017 and then spent 100 days travelling through Australia, finishing its journey at the Opening Ceremony on 4 April 2018, where the message was removed from the Baton and read aloud by [[Charles, Prince of Wales]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.thecgf.com/qbr/|title=Commonwealth Games Federation - Queen's Baton Relay|website=www.thecgf.com|access-date=2017-08-26|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170722223805/http://www.thecgf.com/qbr/|archive-date=22 July 2017|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref> {| class="wikitable mw-collapsible mw-collapsed" |+2018 Queen's Baton Relay cost breakdown<ref name=":8" /> !Event !Cost (A$) |- |Baton Relay launch at [[Buckingham Palace]] |380,000 |- |'''(a) International leg of the journey''' |'''2,100,000''' |- |Flights and accommodation |1,000,000 |- |Photography |164,000 |- |Advertising |17,000 |- |'''(b) Domestic leg of the journey''' |'''4,300,000''' |- |Flights and accommodation |1,500,000 |- |Staging |1,000,000 |- |Uniforms |215,000 |- |Consumables |23,000 |- |Total cost (a) + (b) |6,400,000 |}
===Transport=== [[File:GCLR Set 9 at Broadwater Parklands 2014-09-28.jpg|thumb|[[Gold Coast light rail]]|left]] During the games period, free public transportation within [[Queensland]] region was provided to ticket and accreditation holders. The free transportation services were available on local buses, train and [[Gold Coast light rail]] ([[G:link]]) services in Gold Coast and on [[TransLink (South East Queensland)|TransLink]] and [[QConnect|Qconnect]] bus services in Cairns and Townsville.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.gc2018.com/transport/your-travel-options|title=Your Travel Options {{!}} Gold Coast 2018 Commonwealth Games|website=Gold Coast 2018|language=en|access-date=2018-04-19}}</ref> The Gold Coast light rail system, connected a number of the key games venues including the [[Gold Coast Aquatic Centre|Optus Aquatic Centre]], [[Southport Broadwater Parklands|Broadwater Parklands]] and the [[Gold Coast Convention & Exhibition Centre]] with the major accommodation centres of [[Surfers Paradise]] and [[Broadbeach, Queensland|Broadbeach]] and the Athletes Village at Parklands. An extension to the system was announced in October 2015, connecting the then current terminus at [[Gold Coast University Hospital]] to the [[Gold Coast railway line|railway line to Brisbane]] at [[Helensvale railway station|Helensvale]]. The extension opened in December 2017, in time for the games.<ref>{{cite web|title=Stage two of Gold Coast light rail on track for Commonwealth Games|url=http://statements.qld.gov.au/Statement/2015/10/11/stage-two-of-gold-coast-light-rail-on-track-for-commonwealth-games|publisher=Queensland Government|date=11 October 2015}}</ref>
===Anti-doping=== The [[Australian Sports Anti-Doping Authority]] conducted an anti-doping drive in the months prior to the games, covering around 2500 tests of Australian athletes, as well as 500 tests against international athletes. Three Australians failed drug tests in this process, along with around 20 international athletes, subject to appeal. The Commonwealth Games Federation conducted in-competition testing and, matching protocol at the [[Olympic Games]], launched a sample storage initiative to allow for future testing of samples up to ten years later, should detection technology improve.<ref>[https://www.theaustralian.com.au/sport/2018-commonwealth-games/commonwealth-games-2018-australia-athletes-banned-for-doping/news-story/c9e4a359d34e0b095162536818747932 Commonwealth Games 2018: Australia athletes banned for doping]. ''The Australian'' (2018-04-12). Retrieved 2018-04-15.</ref>
=== Sustainability === The Gold Coast 2018 Commonwealth Games Corporation (GOLDOC) delivered the event with a focus on [[sustainability]] under the guidance of the [[ISO 20121]] event sustainability management system and the [[Global Reporting Initiative]] (GRI) framework Sustainability Reporting Standards.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://gc2018.com/about/sustainability|title=SUSTAINABILITY {{!}} Gold Coast 2018 Commonwealth Games|website=Gold Coast 2018|language=en|access-date=2018-06-12}}</ref> The GOLDOC received the Sustainability Award in the Australian Business Awards 2016 for focusing on sustainable practices and planning in the preparation of the games.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.australianbusinessawards.com.au/2016-winners/australian-business-award-for-sustainability/gold-coast-2018-commonwealth-games-corporation-goldoc/|title=Gold Coast 2018 Commonwealth Games Corporation (GOLDOC)|work=ABA100 Australian Business Awards®|access-date=2018-06-12|language=en-US}}</ref> The GOLDOC headquarters received the 4 Star Green Star – Interiors PILOT rating from the [[Green Building Council of Australia]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://new.gbca.org.au/showcase/projects/goldoc-hq/|title=GOLDOC HQ {{!}} Green Building Council of Australia|website=new.gbca.org.au|language=en|access-date=2018-06-12}}</ref> The new [[Anna Meares Velodrome]], built specifically for the games, is the first velodrome in the world to have full LED broadcast-quality lighting that cuts energy consumption by up to 60% and reduces running costs and carbon emissions.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.archdaily.com/878979/anna-meares-velodrome-cox-architecture|title=Anna Meares Velodrome / Cox Architecture|date=2017-09-04|work=ArchDaily|access-date=2018-06-12|language=en-US}}</ref>
===Opening ceremony=== {{main|2018 Commonwealth Games opening ceremony|2018 Commonwealth Games Parade of Nations}} [[File:Opening Ceremony of 2018 Commonwealth Games.jpg|thumb|2018 Commonwealth Games opening ceremony at [[Carrara Stadium]]]] The opening ceremony was held at [[Carrara Stadium]] in the [[Gold Coast, Australia]], between 20:00 and 22:40 AEST, on 4 April 2018. Tickets for the ceremony started at 100 [[Australian dollars]] with half price tickets available for children.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.gc2018.com/ceremonies/opening-ceremony|title=Opening Ceremony|website=www.gc2018.com/|publisher=Gold Coast 2018 Commonwealth Games Corporation (GOLDOC)|accessdate=20 March 2018}}</ref> The [[Head of the Commonwealth]], Queen [[Elizabeth II]], was represented by her son, [[Charles, Prince of Wales]].<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/commonwealth-games/43641418|title=Commonwealth Games: Gold Coast event starts with colourful opening ceremony|date=4 April 2018|work=BBC Sport|accessdate=5 April 2018}}</ref>
Following tradition, the host of the [[2014 Commonwealth Games|previous games]], [[Scotland at the 2014 Commonwealth Games|Scotland]] entered first, followed by the rest of the [[Europe]]an countries competing.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.insidethegames.biz/articles/1059366/team-scotland-release-gold-coast-2018-parade-tartan|title=Team Scotland release Gold Coast 2018 parade tartan|last=Giles|first=Thomas|date=20 December 2017|website=Insidethegames.biz|publisher=Dunsar Media|access-date=24 March 2018}}</ref> Following this, all countries paraded in alphabetical order from their respective regions. After the European countries entered, countries from Africa, the Americas, Asia, the Caribbean, and lastly Oceania marched in. The host nation of Australia entered last. Each nation was preceded by a placard bearer carrying a sign with the country's name.
===Closing ceremony=== {{main|2018 Commonwealth Games closing ceremony}} The closing ceremony was held at Carrara Stadium on Sunday 15 April and was produced by [[Jack Morton Worldwide]] at a cost of AU$30 million. Australian pop stars [[Guy Sebastian]], [[Samantha Jade]], [[Dami Im]], [[Ricki-Lee Coulter|Ricki Lee]] and [[The Veronicas]] were among the performers along with children's entertainers, [[The Wiggles]].
[[Prince Edward, Earl of Wessex]], declared the Games closed and passed the Commonwealth Games flag to [[Birmingham, England]] which will host the [[2022 Commonwealth Games|2022 Games]].<ref>https://www.insidethegames.biz/articles/1063985/prince-edward-declares-gold-coast-2018-closed-as-flag-passed-to-birmingham-in-ordinary-closing-ceremony</ref>
== Participating teams == There were 71 nations competing at 2018 Commonwealth Games.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.gc2018.com/games/nations-and-territories |title= 71 Nations and Territories. 6 Continents. 2 Billion citizens. 1 commonwealth family |website=www.gc2018.com/ |publisher=Gold Coast 2018 Commonwealth Games Corporation |access-date=8 October 2016}}</ref> [[Maldives]] were scheduled to participate, but in October 2016 they withdrew from the [[Commonwealth of Nations|Commonwealth]].<ref>{{cite web|last=Mackay |first=Duncan|date=14 October 2016|url=http://www.insidethegames.biz/articles/1042634/maldives-set-to-miss-gold-coast-2018-after-resigning-from-commonwealth|title= Maldives set to miss Gold Coast 2018 after resigning from Commonwealth |website=www.insidethegames.biz/ |publisher=Dunsar Media |access-date=16 October 2016}}</ref> [[The Gambia]] returned to the Commonwealth Games after being readmitted as a [[Commonwealth Games Federation]] member on 31 March 2018.<ref name=":1">{{cite web|url=https://www.insidethegames.biz/articles/1063321/gambia-to-compete-at-gold-coast-2018-after-being-readmitted-as-cgf-member|title=Gambia to compete at Gold Coast 2018 after readmitted as CGF member|website=www.insidethegames.biz/ |publisher=Dunsar Media |date=31 March 2018|access-date=3 April 2018}}</ref>

==Calendar== {{2018 Commonwealth Games calendar}}
==Sports== [[File:Carrara Stadium during the 2018 Commonwealth Games.jpg|thumb|[[Carrara Stadium]] during the 2018 Commonwealth Games|right]]The regulations stated that from the 26 approved sports administered by Commonwealth [[Sport governing body|Governing Bodies]], a minimum of ten core sports and maximum of seventeen sports must be included in any Commonwealth Games schedule. The approved sports included the 10 core sports: [[Sport of athletics|athletics]], [[badminton]], [[boxing]], [[Field hockey|hockey]], [[lawn bowls]], [[netball]] (for women), [[rugby sevens]], [[Squash (sport)|squash]], [[List of water sports|swimming]] and [[Olympic weightlifting|weightlifting]]. Integrated [[Disabled sports|disabled competitions]] were also scheduled for the Games in nine sports: swimming, athletics, cycling, table tennis, powerlifting and lawn bowls. Along with these events for the first time EAD events in triathlon were held, with the medals added to the final tally for each nation. A record 38 para events were contested at these games.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.paralympic.org/news/gold-coast-2018-host-largest-commonwealth-para-sport-programme |title=Gold Coast 2018 to host largest Commonwealth para-sport programme |date=3 March 2016|website=www.paralympic.org/ |publisher=[[International Paralympic Committee]] |access-date=23 August 2016}}</ref> On 8 March 2016, [[beach volleyball]] was announced as the 18th sport.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.goldcoastbulletin.com.au/sport/exclusive-beach-volleyball-to-be-played-at-the-2018-gold-coast-commonwealth-games/news-story/0e75284699bda7026d0f84fd14bd5a95|title=Exclusive: Beach volleyball to be played at the 2018 Gold Coast Commonwealth Games |publisher=Gold Coast Bulletin |accessdate=5 April 2016}}</ref>
The program was broadly similar to that of the [[2014 Commonwealth Games]], with the major changes being the dropping of [[judo]], the reintroduction of [[basketball]], the debut of women's rugby sevens and beach volleyball.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.sportsnet.ca/more/womens-rugby-sevens-added-to-commonwealth-games/ |title=Women's rugby added to Commonwealth Games |date=7 October 2014 |website=www.sportsnet.ca/ |publisher=[[Rogers Media]] |access-date=23 August 2016 }}</ref>
On 7 October 2016, it was announced seven new events for women were added to the sport program, meaning there are an equal number of events for men and women. This marks the first time in history that a major [[multi-sport event]] has equality in terms of events. In total 275 events in 18 sports are being contested.<ref>{{cite news|date=7 October 2016 |title=Level playing field for women at 2018 Commonwealth Games|url=http://www.scotsman.com/sport/more-in-sport/level-playing-field-for-women-at-2018-commonwealth-games-1-4251310 |newspaper=[[The Scotsman]] |location=Edinburgh, Scotland |access-date=7 October 2016 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.insidethegames.biz/index.php/articles/1042362/gold-coast-2018-to-offer-same-amount-of-medals-for-men-and-women-after-seven-events-added |title=Gold Coast 2018 to offer same amount of medals for men and women after seven events added|last1=McKay |first1=Duncan|date=7 October 2016 |website=Insidethegames.biz |publisher=Dunsar Media |access-date=7 October 2016}}</ref>
''Numbers in parentheses indicate the number of medal events contested in each sport.'' {{Col-begin|width=100%}} {{Col-1-of-3}} * [[List of water sports|Aquatics]] ** {{GamesSport|Diving (sport)|Events=10}} ** {{GamesSport|Swimming|Events=50}} * {{GamesSport|Athletics|Events=58}} * {{GamesSport|Badminton|Events=6}} * {{GamesSport|Basketball|Events=2}} * {{GamesSport|Beach volleyball|Events=2}} * {{GamesSport|Boxing|Events=16}} {{Col-2-of-3}} * {{GamesSport|Cycling}} ** [[Mountain biking]] <small>(2)</small> ** [[Road bicycle racing|Road]] <small>(4)</small> ** [[Track cycling|Track]] <small>(20)</small> * {{GamesSport|Gymnastics}} ** [[Artistic gymnastics|Artistic]] <small>(14)</small> ** [[Rhythmic gymnastics|Rhythmic]] <small>(6)</small> * {{GamesSport|Hockey|Events=2}} * {{GamesSport|Lawn bowls|Events=10}} {{Col-3-of-3}} * {{GamesSport|Netball|Events=1}} * {{GamesSport|Rugby sevens|Events=2}} * {{GamesSport|Shooting|Events=19}} * {{GamesSport|Squash|Events=5}} * {{GamesSport|Table tennis|Events=9}} * {{GamesSport|Triathlon|Events=5}} * {{GamesSport|Weightlifting|Events=16}} ** {{GamesSport|Powerlifting|Events=4}} * {{GamesSport|Wrestling|Events=12}} {{col-end}}
==Medal table== {{Main|2018 Commonwealth Games medal table}}
Only the top ten successful nations are displayed here. {{:2018 Commonwealth Games medal table}}
== Broadcasting == [[NEP Group|NEP]] Australia was the host broadcaster of the event. It produced [[High-definition video|high definition]] coverage of the event and delivered to the rights-holding broadcasters of other nations.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://gc2018.com/take-part/broadcasting|title=Broadcasting {{!}} Gold Coast 2018 Commonwealth Games|website=Gold Coast 2018|language=en|access-date=2018-06-14}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.nephb.com/about/#nep|title=About - NEP Host Broadcast Gold Coast Commonwealth Games 2018|website=www.nephb.com|access-date=2018-06-14}}</ref> In Australia, the games were broadcast live on three [[Seven Network]] channels - [[7HD]], [[7TWO]] and [[7mate|7Mate]].<ref name=":2">{{Cite web|url=https://commonwealthgames2018.live/|title=Commonwealth Games 2018 live Stream Gold Coast TV Schedule|website=commonwealthgames2018.live|language=en-US|access-date=2018-05-21}}</ref> In the United Kingdom, [[BBC]] provided Commonwealth Games coverage of more than 200 hours across [[BBC One]], [[BBC Two]], [[BBC Red Button]], [[BBC Sport]] website, [[BBC iPlayer]] and [[BBC Radio|BBC radio]].<ref name=":3">{{Cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/mediacentre/mediapacks/commonwealth-games-2018|title=BBC - Gold Coast 2018 Commonwealth Games on the BBC - Media Centre|website=www.bbc.co.uk|language=en-GB|access-date=2018-05-21}}</ref> ESPN provided the games coverage for viewers in the USA.<ref name=":4">{{Cite web|url=https://www.sportcal.com/News/FeaturedNews/26383?size=100&size=100|title=ESPN acquires Commonwealth Games rights in USA for first time in 2018 {{!}} Featured News{{!}} News {{!}} Sportcal|website=www.sportcal.com|access-date=2018-05-21}}</ref> [[Sony Pictures Networks India]] broadcast the games for the viewers in India on three channels - [[Sony Six]], [[Sony Ten#Sony Ten 2|Sony Ten 2]] in English and [[Sony Ten#Sony Ten 3|Sony Ten 3]] in Hindi.<ref name=":5">{{Cite web|url=https://www.rapidtvnews.com/2018022751071/spn-india-gears-up-for-commonwealth-games-coverage.html#axzz5G9XOe1Fy|title=SPN India gears up for Commonwealth Games coverage {{!}} Programming {{!}} News {{!}} Rapid TV News|last=Hawkes|first=Rebecca|website=www.rapidtvnews.com|language=en-gb|access-date=2018-05-21}}</ref>
[[Flow (brand)|Flow]] Sports provided games coverage in the [[Caribbean]] countries such as [[Anguilla]], [[Antigua and Barbuda|Antigua & Barbuda]], [[Aruba]], [[The Bahamas]], [[Barbados]], [[Bermuda]], [[Bonaire]], [[British Virgin Islands]], [[Cayman Islands]], [[Curaçao|Curaçao]], [[Dominica]], [[Dominican Republic]], [[Grenada]], [[Guadeloupe]], [[Guyana]], [[Haiti]], [[Jamaica]], [[Martinique]], [[Montserrat]], [[Netherlands Antilles]], [[Saint Barthélemy|Saint Barthelemy]], [[Saint Kitts and Nevis|Saint Kitts & Nevis]], [[Saint Martin|St. Martin]], [[Saint Vincent and the Grenadines|St. Vincent & the Grenadines]], [[Saint Lucia]], [[Suriname]], [[Trinidad and Tobago|Trinidad & Tobago]] and [[Turks and Caicos Islands|Turks & Caicos]]. Flow Sports provided coverage of the event on Flow Sports 1, Flow Sports 2 and up to three additional "Flow Sports Extra" channels.<ref name=":6" />
The [[New Zealand]] government funded Pacific Cooperation Broadcasting Limited (PCBL) broadcast the event on Pasifika TV in the [[Oceania]]n countries such as [[Cook Islands]], [[Fiji]], [[Nauru]], [[Niue]], [[Papua New Guinea]], [[Samoa]], [[Solomon Islands]], [[Tonga]], [[Vanuatu]], [[Kiribati]] and [[Tuvalu]].<ref name=":7">{{Cite news|url=https://www.pasifikatv.co.nz/latest-news/gold-coast-2018-commonwealth-games-coverage-the-pacific|title=Gold Coast 2018 Commonwealth Games Coverage in the Pacific|date=2018-03-12|work=Pasifika TV|access-date=2018-06-14|language=en}}</ref> {| class="wikitable" !Territory !Rights holder !Ref |- |{{Flag|Australia}} |[[Seven Network]] |<ref name=":2" /> |- |{{Flag|Canada}} |[[DAZN]] |<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.commonwealthgames.ca/news/dazn-canada-lands-exclusive-rights-2018-commonwealth-games.html|title=DAZN CANADA LANDS EXCLUSIVE RIGHTS TO 2018 COMMONWEALTH GAMES {{!}} Commonwealth Games Canada|website=www.commonwealthgames.ca|language=en|access-date=2018-06-14}}</ref> |- |[[Caribbean]] |[[Flow (brand)|Flow]] |<ref name=":6">{{Cite news|url=https://stluciatimes.com/2018/03/26/canoc-grants-flow-broadcast-rights-for-2018-commonwealth-games/|title=CANOC Grants Flow Broadcast Rights for 2018 Commonwealth Games - St. Lucia Times News|date=2018-03-26|work=St. Lucia Times News|access-date=2018-06-14|language=en-US}}</ref> |- |{{Flag|India}} |[[Sony Pictures Networks India]] |<ref name=":5" /> |- | rowspan="2" |{{Flag|Malaysia}} |[[Hypp Sports HD]] |<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://unifi.com.my/tv/commonwealth.html|title=unifi TV {{!}} unifi Commonwealth Games|website=unifi.com.my|language=en|access-date=2018-07-29}}</ref> |- |[[Astro Arena (TV channel)|Astro Arena]] |<ref>{{Cite Malaysian Athletes at the Gold Coast 2018 Commonwealth Games {{!}} Press Release {{!}} Mediaroom {{!}} Astro|last=Astro.com.my|website=www.astro.com.my|language=en-US|access-date=2018-05-21}}</ref> |- |{{Flag|New Zealand}} |[[TVNZ]] |<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.olympic.org.nz/news/tvnz-announces-gold-coast-2018-commonwealth-games-coverage/|title=TVNZ announces Gold Coast 2018 Commonwealth Games coverage {{!}} New Zealand Olympic Team|date=2018-03-01|work=New Zealand Olympic Team|access-date=2018-05-21|language=en}}</ref> |- |[[Oceania]] |PCBL |<ref name=":7" /> |- |{{Flag|Singapore}} |[[Mediacorp]] |<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.mediacorp.sg/en/corporate/mediacorp-in-the-news/media-releases/catch-team-singapore-at-gold-coast-2018-commonwealth-games-on-10062456|title=Mediacorp : Catch Team Singapore at Gold Coast 2018 Commonwealth Games on Mediacorp's breadth of platforms|work=Mediacorp|access-date=2018-06-14|language=en}}</ref> |- |{{Flag|South Africa}} |[[SuperSport (South African TV channel)|SuperSport]] |<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.thesouthafrican.com/commonwealth-games-2018-when-is-the-opening-ceremony-and-how-to-watch/|title=Everything you need to know about the 2018 Commonwealth Games opening ceremony|last=Haden|first=Alexis|date=2018-03-31|work=The South African|access-date=2018-06-14|language=en-US}}</ref> |- |{{Flag|United Kingdom}} |[[BBC]] |<ref name=":3" /> |- |{{Flag|United States}} |[[ESPN]] |<ref name=":4" /> |}
==Marketing== ===Motto=== The official motto for the 2018 Commonwealth Games was "Share the Dream". It was chosen to highlight the dreams and experience at the games that were shared by participants of the games, ranging from athletes to volunteers and the host country Australia to the world including the Commonwealth nations.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.gc2018.com/games|title=The Games}}</ref>
===Emblem=== The emblem was launched on 4 April 2013, which marked exactly five years until its opening ceremony.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.sportskeeda.com/sports/emblem-unveiled-for-2018-commonwealth-games|title=Emblem unveiled for 2018 Commonwealth Games|date=2013-04-04|access-date=2018-04-25}}</ref> It was unveiled at the [[Southport Broadwater Parklands]]. It was designed by the [[New South Wales]] based brand consultancy WiteKite.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://mumbrella.com.au/gold-coast-commonwealth-games-logo-unveiled-149025|title=Gold Coast Games logo unveiled - Mumbrella|date=2013-04-04|work=Mumbrella|access-date=2018-04-25|language=en-US}}</ref> The emblem of the 2018 Commonwealth Games was a silhouette of the skyline and landscape of Gold Coast, the host city of the games.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.gc2018.com/emblem|title=Emblem}}</ref> Nigel Chamier <small>[[Order of Australia|OAM]]</small>, former Chairman of the GOLDOC, said that it was the result of months of market research.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.brisbanetimes.com.au/national/queensland/commonwealth-games-emblem-revealed-20130404-2h80s.html|title=Commonwealth Games emblem revealed|date=2013-04-03|website=Brisbane Times|language=en|access-date=2018-04-25}}</ref>
===Mascot=== [[File:Borobi2018.jpg|thumb|Borobi, the mascot of the 2018 Commonwealth Games|203x203px]]{{main|Borobi (mascot)}} Borobi was named as the mascot of the 2018 Commonwealth Games in 2016. Borobi is a blue koala, with indigenous markings on its body. The term "borobi" means koala in the [[Yugambeh language]], spoken by the indigenous [[Yugambeh people]] of the Gold Coast and surrounding areas.<ref>{{cite news |last=Larkins|first=Damien |date=3 April 2016 |title=Blue koala Borobi revealed as mascot for 2018 Gold Coast Commonwealth Games |url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2016-04-04/2018-gold-coast-commonwealth-games-mascot-borobi-revealed/7295724 |work=[[ABC News (Australia)]] |location=Sydney, New South Wales, Australia|access-date=5 November 2017 }}</ref> The song <nowiki>''Days of Gold''</nowiki> composed by the Australian Duo band [[Busby Marou]], which was released on 17 October 2014, was considered as the official song of the Mascot Borobi.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.sbs.com.au/nitv/nitv-news/article/2016/04/04/duo-behind-theme-song-commonwealth-games-mascot-borobi-classic-reconciliation|title=Duo behind theme song for Commonwealth Games' mascot Borobi a 'classic reconciliation model'|work=NITV|access-date=2018-06-14|language=en}}</ref>
=== Sponsors === [[File:Comm Games 2018 - Woolworths display (Warwick).jpg|left|thumb|Commonwealth Games display at a [[Woolworths Supermarkets|Woolworths supermarket]] in [[Warwick, Queensland|Warwick]], [[Western Australia]]]] The official partners of the games were [[The Star Gold Coast]], [[Griffith University]], [[TAFE Queensland]], [[Longines]], [[Optus]], [[Atos]] and [[Woolworths Supermarkets]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://gc2018.com/sponsors|title=SPONSORS {{!}} Gold Coast 2018 Commonwealth Games|website=Gold Coast 2018|language=en|access-date=2018-06-04}}</ref> [[Griffith University]] was also the Creative Arts partner of the games and Presenting partner of the [[Gold Coast Marathon]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://gc2018.com/sponsor/griffith-university|title=Griffith University {{!}} Gold Coast 2018 Commonwealth Games|website=Gold Coast 2018|language=en|access-date=2018-06-04}}</ref> [[TAFE Queensland]] was responsible for providing vocational education and training program for the volunteers of the games.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://gc2018.com/sponsor/tafe-queensland|title=TAFE QUEENSLAND {{!}} Gold Coast 2018 Commonwealth Games|website=Gold Coast 2018|language=en|access-date=2018-06-04}}</ref> [[Longines]] served as the official timekeeper of the games.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://gc2018.com/sponsor/longines|title=LONGINES {{!}} Gold Coast 2018 Commonwealth Games|website=Gold Coast 2018|language=en|access-date=2018-06-04}}</ref>
=== Official song === The official song of the 2018 Commonwealth Games <nowiki>''</nowiki>[[Welcome to Earth (song)|Welcome to Earth]]<nowiki>''</nowiki> was recorded by the Australian Singer [[Delta Goodrem]]. The song was performed for the first time by Goodrem during the [[2018 Commonwealth Games opening ceremony|opening ceremony]] of the games.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.auspop.com.au/2018/04/welcome-to-earth-new-delta-single/|title=WELCOME TO EARTH, NEW DELTA SINGLE|date=5 April 2018|publisher=auspOp|accessdate=12 May 2018}}</ref> The song was worldwide released on 5 April 2018 in Delta Goodrem's official [[YouTube|YouTube]] channel.<ref>{{Citation|last=DeltaGoodremVEVO|title=Delta Goodrem - Welcome to Earth (Audio)|date=2018-04-04|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=oWPnU_wRj04|accessdate=2018-06-05}}</ref>
== Concerns and controversies ==
=== Missing athletes === At least 13 athletes from four countries - Cameroon, Uganda, Rwanda, and Sierra Leone - absconded during or immediately after the Games. Some missed their competitions.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.news.com.au/sport/commonwealth-games/still-no-sign-of-missing-african-commonwealth-games-athletes/news-story/9b0d197e66c6e7006fcdf2e9bfa98cd4|title=Still no sign of missing African Commonwealth Games athletes|work=NewsComAu|access-date=2018-04-19}}</ref> Athletes regularly abscond during major sporting events, and many subsequently claim asylum in their host countries. Most hold nationalities that are deemed high-risk by immigration authorities and find it impossible to get visas outside of exceptional events, such as major games.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2018/apr/11/cameroon-athletes-missing-from-commonwealth-games|title=Cameroon athletes missing from Commonwealth Games|last=Doherty|first=Ben|date=2018-04-11|website=the Guardian|language=en|access-date=2018-04-19}}</ref>
A month after the games ended, officials estimated that fifty athletes had remained in Australia illegally, with another 200 staying in the country on visas.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-australia-44194069 |title=Commonwealth Games: Fifty athletes in Australia 'illegally' |work=BBC News |accessdate=21 May 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/2018/may/21/almost-200-commonwealth-games-athletes-and-officials-seek-asylum-in-australia |title=Almost 200 Commonwealth Games athletes and officials seek asylum in Australia |work=The Guardian |accessdate=21 May 2018}}</ref>
=== Criticism of the closing ceremony === The organising committee decided to bring in the athletes before the start of the closing ceremony. This caused an uproar on social media as, contrary to public expectations, none of the athletes were shown entering the stadium during the ceremony. Broadcast rights holders [[Seven Network|Channel 7]] complained on air about the decision and concluded that, "it hasn't really lived up to expectations". Many spectators and athletes left during the ceremony, resulting in a half-empty stadium for much of the event.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2018-04-15/channel-seven-rip-into-commonwealth-games-closing-ceremony/9661088|title=Commonwealth Games closing ceremony slammed on social media as Channel Seven hosts open fire|date=15 April 2018|work=[[Australian Broadcasting Corporation]] (ABC)|access-date=15 April 2018|location=Sydney, Australia}}</ref> Following this, the [[ABC News (Australia)|ABC]] claimed that Channel 7 was briefed on the closing ceremony schedule,<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2018-04-16/commonwealth-games-closing-ceremony-footage-channel-seven/9663266|title=Seven was briefed on closing ceremony|date=2018-04-16|work=ABC News|access-date=2018-04-17|language=en-AU}}</ref> a claim which Channel 7 later refuted.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.smh.com.au/entertainment/tv-and-radio/griggs-hits-back-at-claims-channel-seven-knew-plan-to-snub-athletes-20180416-p4z9yu.html|title=Griggs hits back at claims Channel Seven knew plan to snub athletes|last=Cunningham|first=Melissa|date=2018-04-16|website=The Sydney Morning Herald|language=en|access-date=2018-04-17}}</ref>
<!--===Doping case=== On May 31, 2018, the first positive case of doping was announced by the [[International Weightlifting Federation]] (IWF). [[Khumukcham Sanjita Chanu]] of [[India at the 2018 Commonwealth Games|India]] who was won the gold medal at [[Weightlifting at the 2018 Commonwealth Games – Women's 53 kg|Weightlifting Women's 53 kg]] was caught on the anti-doping test and immediately lost her medal, Papua New Guinea athlete [[Dika Toua]] was promoted to silver for gold, the Canadian [[Rachel Leblanc-Bazinet]] rose to second place and the Sri Lankan athlete Chamari Warnakulasuriya moved up to third place. <ref>[https://www.insidethegames.biz/articles/1065685/indian-gold-medallist-and-spaniard-among-new-weightlifting-positives]. ''Inside The Games'' (2018-05-31). Retrieved 2018-05-31.</ref>-->
